I continue walking, finding an old Asian lady with a straw hat on tending to a garden full of succulents, the perfect type of plants to grow in this hot weather. She too is too focused on her work to notice me. At the end of the street, where the road widens to form the court, only one person has his garage door open, mainly due to the probable heat in his garage as he diligently works on his car. He looks my way for a brief second before walking back in to grab a tool from his tool box.

I get to the end of the street, where a staircase leads down in between two yards to a paved path below. Down here, where the tall tree shade the walkway, it's considerably cooler. If there were running water, it would be a lot more cooler, but due to this drought, there is no water to be found. Only a dry creek bed with stagnant puddles of water hear and there. A slight breeze although, keeps the place from smelling too bad.

Once on the path, I go to my right, assuming the path to the left with take me under an overpass that the main street goes over. I had planned to explore more of the neighborhood and it's clear the residential area ends to the left. I might as well go to the right and see where it takes me.

I walk what seems to be just a half mile before the path no longer is a leveled walkway. The incline rises, but it's mild and not too extreme. The surrounding residences, their foundations and even the direction of the streets rise as the path goes up. It doesn't go up too far and about another half mile, it becomes level again, though with much more trees than the bottom.

I don't get very far when I hear something that cannot be seen with my eyes just yet. What do I hear?
12133333313.title: Dry Creek

choices: None other than my roommate Ricky, who was out looking for me
First, a dog, then his human owner
An off-duty police officer
121333333132.content:
It's no wonder the breeze that blows through the corridor the pathway is paved through gets colder. I had just heard the skies above bellow out a roaring amount of thunder, luckily I did not see a flash of lightning. Maybe it's because the trees up here are more thicker and blocks any view apart from the gaps in between houses.

I no time, the rain starts pouring down. What was dry ground and dry creek, becomes slick, muddy ground and the beginnings of a creek resurrected. This bogus storm must have been a surprise for everyone. Unfortunately, for me, i don't have a garage or any type of shelter I can use to get out of the rain. The trees help for a moment, but once the rain starts seeping down from the branches, then it gets bad. I can only protect myself with my hood, but that's it. My sweater by now is already soaked, enough that the cold has touched my skin underneath the fabric. My shorts and legs are in the same condition. My shoes are the worst, for the pathway had started descending and a couple times, the soles of my shoes had slipped on some slick areas on the pavement. I had to find purchase on a part of the path that wasn't too slick.

I have been able to save myself a couple times, but the incline just now became a bit more steeper. Not drastically, but by a couple degrees. The creek next to me, possibly a twin from the one I saw before, flows down with much force that it laps up the bank, making the ground there even more muddy. It's a good thing that the city installed a fenced rail to prevent slippage into the creek, but the bad news is that with the force of the water, some of the mud have mixed with the watery current down onto the pavement. Even I know I won't have enough traction to get down it safely.

But where can I go. There are no outlets out of this place. The nearest one was the staircase that I had used to get down here in the first place. I have no choice but to go down. I take it slow, one step at a time. I put one foot onto the stream running down the pavement and put my weight on it. The rubber sole holds. Not sure that my foot would take all the weight, I slowly inch my other foot along the ground, passing my planted foot until I can find purchase on another section with my other foot. The whole procedure takes time, at least ten minutes, though it could have been longer. But I successfully, get to the bottom, where it levels out and luckily, I find an outlet into the neighborhood.

I immediately take it and rush to find some type of shelter to get out of the pouring rain. In my rush, my foot steps on the side of the path where the material had eroded. When my foot steps on it, the material gives way and when adding the water pattering all around me, the friction is lost and the joint of my ankle goes too far, causing searing pain at the bottom of my leg. I scream and cry as I lose my balance, splashing onto wet grass. Right now, the wetness is the least of my concern. With my crippled ankle, it'll take forever to get back to the house.

Fortunately, the outlet had taken me to another park, but in a different neighborhood. I find that it's obviously empty, but I have a sliver of hope that there might be someone nearby that can help. "Hello! Anybody there! I need help!" I shout out, but stop as the pain comes back again.

Who comes to my aid?
121333333132.title: Pouring Rain

choices: Go to my parents' house
Go to his childhood home
Anywhere but here (no decision)
1213333331321.content:
"Jo?" a familiar voice calls out, using the very name I called myself. I turn my head to the voice and see none other than the closest roommate out of the three that lives in the house. Ricky is somehow relieved to see me, though the reasons may be different. He runs to me and asks, "What happened?"

I start to explain, "Well, I was caught out in this storm and my ankle slipped too far, spraining it or---," but Ricky interrupts me.

"Never mind that, we need to get out of here," he says out of nowhere. "It's not safe." Before I can ask what is wrong or what happened that has caused him to act this way, he takes me into his arms and carries me into the thick of the bushes. He lays me down on the moist floor, but it's not the mud possibly soiling my clothes that has my concern. Looking through the openings between the thin stems of the bush, I can see in the distance an empty parking lot and what looks to be Ricky's truck, parked in a weird position, like he was in a hurry to get that certain spot. Seconds later two SUVs race into the parking lot and after stopping near Ricky's truck, men in suits wielding handguns exit out of the vehicles and investigate the truck. They find it empty and the leader of the group, who's bald, command the others to spread out in hopes of finding the person who was driving that truck.

"Who are they, Ricky?" I ask, but he doesn't answer. He instead puts a hand over my mouth to silence me and it turns out that one of the men is headed straight here. Fortunately, the bushes on this part of the park is too thick and though he tries to wedge himself in, he is pushed back out by the branches. The man leaves to investigate another part, never coming back to the brush.

The men look through every part of the park, even the path that leads to the path alongside the creek. Ricky and I wait until they return, as they are on their radios telling the man in charge that who they are looking for has run off along the creek. The men withdraw from the park and enter back into their SUV's and drive away.

Ricky let's go of my face and slumps down next to me, catching his breath. "Who were they, Ricky?" I ask my question once more.

"They were here for the glove and any witnesses who may have seen what it's capable of," he tells me. "I was in my room when Sonny and a woman entered the house. They used that time to force their way in. The took the glove and ever turned Sonny into a woman. I escaped out the window, but they heard me get into my car. I knew you went out because no one would leave the door unlocked if they had a key to unlock it. That's how they got in, though."

"Sorry about that," I apologize.

"Not your fault. Tyrone. If he didn't bring that glove and change us, we wouldn't be in this mess," Ricky reassures me. "Now he's probably a woman alongside Sonny, having all sorts of cruel stuff done to him." He catches his breath as he looks out into the park. "We have to get out of here. We can't go back to the house. If those guys are smart, they will probably turn the house upside-down looking for something that can help them track us down. I'll probably have to ditch my truck too."

"How will we get out of here? And where will we go?" I ask him. He looks around again, seeing if the coast is clear, and answers. What does he decide on?
1213333331321.title: On The Run

choices: To the hospital, of course
To his house
Back to my house, which I tell him the location
1213333331322.content:
Not even a minute has passed when I hear, apart from the pouring droplets hitting various objects around me, the jingling of a bell. I look in the direction of the peculiar sound and find a dog, whose breed is a Shiba Inu, a favorite of mine, running over to me. He slows down meters before he meets me and when he gets to where I'm laying, he looks behind him and barks. He does this for about thirty seconds, which gives me enough time to observe how his short fur, though known to be groomed off during the summertime, soaked with the rain. His light, golden fur is more of a light, muddy brown when its all wet. I also reach over for the dog's collar, which has a tag with the name "Dango" on it. I wonder why your name is Dango, I speak in my mind. The collar also has a simple rope leash attached to it, but no owner attached to the other end.

"Dango!" a man's voice calls out from afar. "Dango! Where'd you run off to buddy!" A man with a bright yellow coat appears from behind a bush. I look over and he rushes to where his dog is standing. "Who did you find, boy?" He then addresses me. "Are you hurt miss? What happened?"

The man goes over to me, but due to the pain in my ankle and his hood, I can barely see his face. I tell him of my injury, "I slipped and fell as I was coming up the path. The rain started pouring when I was at the creek, but luckily I found this park."

"You're lucky Dango found you when he did," the man says. "We were trying out this park when it suddenly started raining. We thought this drought was going to last forever. But enough, talk, let's get you out of her and someplace dry. Can you walk?"

"I haven't tried," I say, "but I'm sure my ankle hurts a lot."

"You couldn't even try to get up when there isn't anything to hold onto that is not wet. Here, let me help you up," the man says and immediately wraps his arm around my shoulders, snaking his forearm underneath my armpit. While holding onto the hand opposite the armpit he has supported, he lifts me upright, minding to not put any pressure on my afflicted ankle. "Now, can you put any weight on your foot?"

"I'll try," I tell him and as he holds onto me, I transfer my weight from my left foot, which feels fine, to my right foot. As soon as the sole of my right foot is level with the ground, stinging pain shoots up my leg. I yelp in pain and my response is to lift my foot and leave it hanging.

"This won't do," the man tells me. "The parking lot is at the other end of this park and walking there will take a long time. I'm going to have to carry you, miss, is that alright?"

Surely, if we just start walking to the parking lot, we will have to stop due to my ankle not being able to take it. There is no other option. If there was, I would have taken it, but I will have to just trust this man. Judging by his speech, he doesn't want to carry me out of respect for a stranger. At least he asked me before doing it. "That's alright, thank you," I respond and give him my appreciation. He wastes no time in supporting my torso in the same fashion as he lifted me to my feet a minute before. He then uses his other arm to support my thighs, which keeps the ankle hanging with no pressure acting on it.

I keep my head down, not wanting to lock eyes with the man. I don't want to be attracted to a stranger. I'd rather be attracted and be touched by one of my roommates than a stranger who I don't know. I instead watch as the dog follows us and runs ahead of us. A smile forms on my lips, not for the rescuer, but for his dog.

The man carries me in silence, all the way to his car, which is an SUV. He is able to open the passenger door and gently place me onto the seat, again, minding not to hit my foot anywhere in the car. Once I'm seated, he closes the door and opens the rear door to let the dog inside. He then gets into the driver's seat and turns over the engine. I keep my gaze down into my lap, not wanting to see and know who has rescued me. I hear him take off his hood and sigh in response to the rain. Heck, I'm sighing as well, glad to be out of the storm.

The man speaks to me, "We need to take you somewhere you can get that ankle treated."

Where does he take me?
1213333331322.title: Man's Best Friend

choices: It's my dad
It's my older brother
It's my Physical Ed teacher from high school
12133333313222.content:
"It's a good thing I work in a hospital and I know first aid. I have things at my house that I can treat your injury. It's not that far," the man tells me, "if that's okay with you of course."

I weight my options. If we go to a hospital, which I'm sure is much farther away, then it will be a long time before we get there. If I go to his house, which I assume is in this neighborhood, I will receive treatment much sooner. The pain in my ankle removes my reluctance to trust a stranger, even when he has shown me traits of a good samaritan. "That's okay," I tell him simply.

I assume he silently affirms my agreement to allow him to take me to his house. It's funny that I don't feel at all standoffish towards him, though it's the pain in my leg that prevents either of us to bond in this situation. He pulls out of the parking lot and drives onto the road. He rounds the park to a street that goes down an incline. Despite the stinging, I allow my eyes to catch a glimpse of the much larger house in this part of the neighborhood. My house surely was on a hill, or at the very least, on the rim of this valley we are now driving in. In no time, the man drives his SUV to a towering multi-storied house on the corner of a leveled street and a upward-sloping one.

The man's driveway is short and a bit on the slope, but it soon becomes leveled once we are on the faded pink bricks that make up the driveway. He drive his truck into the now opened garage. By the looks of it, he recently moved in. He turns off his car and wastes no time getting himself and his dog out. He opens my door and pauses, probably to look over my body and the condition it's in. There is nothing much to look and stare at save for my wet legs, though I hope he's not thinking perverse thoughts in his mind.

"I'm going to have to carry you again, for I have a lot of stairs in my house," he tells me. "Is that okay?"

I nod in response and he carefully places his arms in the same places he support in order to lift me up from the wet ground at the park. I have to tuck myself tight in order not to hit my ankle on the dashboard, the side of the seat or the door. The man successfully lifts me from my seat and out of the car, but thinking my foot is safe from further harm, I untuck my body, causing my injured foot to reach out to the edge of the open door, sending stinging pain from my toes to my pelvis. "Ahhh!" I yelp out in pain.

"What happened?"he asks as he stops to look at my face. My eyes widen as I see his face. Why am I so surprised?
12133333313222.title: Tower in a Valley

choices: The clothes belong to his late wife of one year
The clothes belong to his sister, who lived with him previously
His secret is that he used to crossdress in the very clothes in the bag.
121333333132223.content:
Officially, when in class, his students would address him as Mr. Haynes. The guys who have taken a liking to him informally called him Coach, even though he had never coached any sports teams. The ladies would affectionately call him by his first name, Noah. He looks the same to me, though, he's a bit older, a bit more mature, but there is no mistaking his youthful face. It's no wonder why all the girls in P.E. class swoon at the sight of him. Seeing him with the eyes of a young woman, I'm sure at this very moment, I'm doing the same, though with a bit of silence on my part. I try to make an excuse as to why I pause. "I hit my foot on the car door," I say with a bit of a giggle, but it is subdued with the throbbing pain in my ankle.

He giggles with me and just the sound of it makes the pain go away. I don't want to say that his face is dreamy, but it feels just as it sounds. He walks me to the door, which is opened by the semi-wet dog. He then proceeds to climb two flights of stairs, passing the foyer and a couple doors to which I believe are bedrooms, and getting to a floor that sports a living room, a dining room and a kitchen, all connected to each other without the need for additional walls or doors. Save for a bathroom, the whole floor is one big room that combines three certain areas.

He carries me to the couch, which he lays me down on, supporting my neck with a pillow and grabbing two more to raise my injured ankle. He tells me why he's doing what he's doing. "I have to elevate your injury higher than your heart so we can ease the swelling. It's a good thing this looks fine, but just in case, we need it to be cold," he explains and disappears after he takes off the shoe on my afflicted foot. He comes back holding an unopened bag of frozen peas and without warning, places it on my ankle. The sheer cold causes me to moan, but I settle down after the pain starts to subside and eventually become numb after a few minutes.

I relax as the Noah disappears to go downstairs, while the still semi-wet dog sits happily at my side. Outside, the rain continues to pour over the whole city, though it seems it pours buckets over the house compared to the droplets everywhere else. The dog nuzzles at my hand and I reach over to pet him and scratch him behind his ears. I speak to the dog, "Thank you, boy. Without you, I wouldn't have gotten help."

"He returns the favor," Mr. Haynes says as he reappears with a large stack of towels. By the looks of it, he has discarded his wet clothes with dry ones. He returns with a pair of sweats and a darker-colored hoodie. "Come on, boy," he says to the dog. The dog obeys him and allows itself to be dried with a towel, though, as dogs do, he shakes and twists his whole body around so he can get all the moisture that the towel couldn't absorb out, all at the cost of making the two of us humans wetter. As the dog runs off to do whatever dogs do, Noah speaks up. "He's a rescued dog. I adopted him when my neighbor couldn't take care of him. This was when I was living in my roommates house. I could tell he was glad to be out of that home and under my care. I tell you, he has saved my life so many times. But enough about him, let's see how that ankle is doing. Can you sit up?"

I nod and try to manage resting my back on the couch's large cushions and set myself upright. Noah, after grabbing an ottoman and sitting himself in front of me, removes the bag of peas and gently lifts my ankle off the pillows and onto his lap. His warm hands hold my foot, transferring his heat into the cold of my toes and sole. He also takes off my sock, which is drenched. He dries my foot with a towel and then gently pokes in certain places in order to get a response. He starts by poking the underside of my heel and I respond my tilting my head to one side and give him an expression telling him that it's mild and it's not painful. He moves to the inside part of my ankle.

I bite my lip, to which his asks, "Any pain there?"

I shake my head and tell him, "Only a little bit."

He circles around to the front of my ankle, poking it with his thumb. I give him the mild expression, which he takes into consideration and then moves backwards to the back of my heel. He runs two fingers along the length of the hard part and again I give him the sign that it's only mild and doesn't hurt as much. He creeps sideways to the outer part of my ankle and I audibly moan and hiss. He traces underneath the flared portion and I clench at the cushions. "So this is where it hurts?" he asks.

"Yes," I simply say.

"Well, it's good news," he says, "There is hardly any swelling and it's only located in one spot on your foot. All you would need is to keep your weight off the leg and you'll be fine. But considering it's raining outside and your house is probably much farther than where I found you, I have a way to treat this so it heals faster."

All I have is appreciation for him and I say, "Thank you, Sir."

"Don't thank me. Heck, it's Dango here you have thanked already for finding you. Say, I didn't introduce myself," he responds.

"I already know who you are," I tell him from out of nowhere. He sports an inquisitive expression on his face. "You used to be the P.E. teacher at Triumph High."

"Wait, how do you know me?" he asks.

"I was a student in your class, in 2010," I tell him.

Noah still looks puzzled. He gets to his feet, after gently placing my leg on the ottoman. He gestures to me with his hand to wait and he disappears again, possibly to retrieve something. I see him again as he brings back a bandage and a fastener as well as what looks like a brown jar of liquid. He sets his things down and positions his lap underneath my heel once more. "That was my most memorable year, but also my last year at that school. I'm afraid I don't recognize you," he tells me.

"I was expecting you didn't recognize me. I didn't really hang around after class nor said hello in passing," I tell him as he opens the bottle and let out a pleasant aroma. "Coconut oil?"

Noah's puzzling look transforms to a grin. "A tried and true substance with millions of uses. Let it become a paste and then you can use it as rubbing oil," he explains. He takes a dime-sized dollop of the slightly-opaque paste that looks like light green wax with two fingers and applies it to the affected area. He gently massages the oil into my skin, which is soothing despite the pain rising a bit as he touches the epicenter. I watch him as he becomes focused in treating me and I blush, though I catch myself getting attracted to him. I have to take a deep breath all while trying to stay quiet as the painful spot slowly subsides with the continued rubbing. I remove my hood due to myself getting hot, but it seems that the wetness acts similarly to sweat.

Noah carefully takes the bandage and wraps it around my ankle, my foot, and my lower leg to properly secured it and prevent it from moving too much. "That should do it," Noah says, "Now, you should be able to walk with little pain, but I suggest not going to the park in this weather or run on that foot." He backs up so he can set my foot down on the ground. Without warning, he pulls my arms so that I can stand on my own two feet, but I end up clutching to him as I pivot forward to much. Awkwardly, I push off of him so that I'm not in his personal space. "That's alright. I think you might have to rest up and get into some dry clothes. Here's a towel." Noah hands me a towel so I can dry my skin. "I should have some clothes in the boxes in the garage."

Again he leaves me to go downstairs. I try my hand at walking with my injury. There is slight pain, but the bandage prevents my foot or ankle from moving too much. I can only limp at a slow pace. The wet clothes on my body doesn't help much either. Fortunately, Noah does not take long and he comes back with a duffel bag of clothes. When I take some out, I'm surprised to find articles of clothing belong to a woman. Shirts, pants, shorts, skirts and even underwear. I give Noah a puzzling look as to why he, a man who lives by himself with his dog, would have women's clothes in his possession. He catches my look, takes a deep breath and tells me...what?

When I pull out a bra and a small shirt from the bag, I'm lost for words. One, I'm glad that this man has clothes that are not oversized for me to wear, but two, why does he have them in the first place. "They're my sister's clothes," he tells me. I give him a look that casts doubt on his sorry attempt at an excuse, but it's not an excuse. He begins to explain the reason. "She used to live with me when I had my previous place. This particular bag was the one she took when she recently went camping with me and her boyfriend. One morning, I woke up alone in the tent and I find that she leaves this bag along with all the food in the coolers. It turns out she and her boyfriend eloped together, taking all their things and driving away. That's why I have it." His explanation doesn't seem plausible. He then adds, "I just tossed in a box with my sister's name on it. I don't even think they've been washed."

I smell the clothes and discover the same musty smell on all of them. The smell isn't pungent like a man's, but it's there, as evidence. "Ooh," I exclaim as I smell the clothes. "I guess you're telling the truth."

"Well, there is a bathroom just right here," he tells me, pointing out a door that leads into a small bathroom right behind his flat-screen TV. "Or if you need anymore privacy, there should be an empty bedroom with a mirror and a mattress downstairs."

"Don't you need help unpacking?" I ask Noah.

"I don't want you walking more than you have to on that leg," he responds.

"I'm okay, really," I tell him. "I don't have to walk up a lot of steps and I'll let you carry the heavy stuff. I just want to help in repayment for saving me." I look into his face, watching for any change in mood. When he doesn't change in the ten seconds I wait for his response, I walk around him and make my way downstairs. I hear and sense him follow me.

Once in the garage, I find Dango the Shiba Inu sleeping next to a couch that sit on the back wall, opposite the door. Around him are boxes stacked on top of each other. On some of the boxes, those that are mostly on the bottom, are label with large black letters that form the word "FRAGILE." I figure they are the heavy ones and the ones that Noah doesn't want me to carry. I agree with the assumption due to my injured ankle. If I was to carry one, I would probably end up breaking the contents inside if I fall. I might even break something in my weak body as well.

I pick small and medium boxes, but I'm saddened to find that most of them are too heavy for me to carry. I turn around and see Noah leaning on the doorway with a smug look on his face. "What's so funny?" i ask.

"You. I told you that I don't want you walking more than you have to. With all these boxes, you'll be doing a lot of careful walking," he says. "It's funny seeing you trying to carry such a small, but heavy box. I don't know, it's cute." He walks over to me and takes me by the wrist and walks me back up to the floor above. Great, Jo, you've figured out a way to think you're cute, I say to myself in my mind. I was attempting not to be attractive, or at the very least, be cute, but in my attempt to help him, I've only help him realize that I'm the latter. Maybe I shouldn't help him, but then again, my generous soul doesn't want to leave all the work to him. I don't think the dog will help him. And him, living alone with no friends to help him. i'm his best offer if he ever takes it. Noah leads me into the kitchen, to the box that he had set down on the counter. "I do need help unpacking. Just leave the heavy lifting or reaching to me." Before leaving, he pats my head, which is awkward. The funny gesture has got me blushing, again.

A box cutter sits on the counter, so I take it and push the switch so the blade is unsheathed. I cut open the box and find cans of food inside. Noah had told me that he needed help unpacking, but does he want me to fill the cupboards with them? It would help if he gave me his game plan for decorating his house. So instead of going out of my own way and do the task provided with no guidance, I just try to do the simple task of just unpacking. Using the space of the counter, I take out the cans and place them on the surface, further organizing them by food type and then by the varieties of that food type.

Noah comes back with another box, which he sets down on the floor after seeing that his counter space has been used up. He opens the box that he carries up, which turns out to be plates of differing kinds. Some are decorative and only used to display and the rest are for putting food on them and eating off of them. "Hey, I didn't catch your name," Noah says.

I immediately tell him, "Oh, it's Jocelynn, but Jo is fine." I find that the box that I've unpacked is empty, so I take it off the counter and toss it to the floor.

"So Jo," he starts, "you already know me as the P.E. teacher you had when you were at Triumph in 2010, right?"

"Mm-hmm," i agree. "I think I was 16 then, my sophomore year."

"So you already know my name then?" he asks.

I lie to him, knowing that his name is Noah, but changing it to something close. "Nolan?" I ask, attempting not to be the creepy girl from his physical education days.

"It's Noah, actually. I've had so many students, it's hard to remember their names. I don't recall seeing your name on my roster, then again, I have had a lot of students in my class," Noah explains. "If you want, you don't have to address me as Sir or Mr. Haynes. Just Noah is fine."

"So Noah," I start, much like he did before with my name, "Where did you want to put these?" I show him the collection of canned food on the counter.

"Wow, Jo, I didn't even notice you organized them," Noah says with apparent surprise on his face. "Well, the pantry I believe is right here to the left of the fridge." He leads me to a door that's a foot away from the refrigerator. When he opens it, closet that is like a mini walk-in closet is revealed to be inside. The walls have shelves are varying heights mounted. "Just fill the shelves as much as you can and I can do the higher stuff."

I do just that, carrying an armful of cans and being careful not to drop any on the floor as I carry them from the counter, around the kitchen island and to the open pantry. After just a couple trips, my pace starts to slow, but fortunately, Noah sees the struggle and drops whatever he's doing at the moment and helps me by letting stay at the pantry while he transports the cans over to me. I find just standing still and just using my arms is better than using an injured leg and arms to do work by myself. I get comfortable as one shelf begins to be filled. "So Noah, what did you do after the P.E. teaching stuff?" I ask out of the blue.

"Oh, well, I was actually a temp gym teacher because another teacher was hospitalized. I was actually a temp for three years, can you believe that?" he explains. "I did it for the money, but since I was young, I related to the students I had. After that, I finished up school, worked my ass off at an apprenticeship at a hospital and landed a job as a physical therapist."

"Physical therapist? So that's how you're good at treating my ankle," I point out.

"I was good at finding the problem, but I owe it to my grandpa for showing me a good remedy," he tells me in response. He then redirects with the unpacking. "I have another box of canned goods downstairs, but the good thing is that there's only one more. Just wait here and I'll bring it up."

He comes back and does me a favor and sets the box on the floor near the pantry. This time i won't have to do any unnecessary walking. He chuckles at the notion. "If I knew where she was with her boyfriend, I would send her your regards, but i don't think she'll be coming back for that outfit. Not bad, by the way. A bit small---" he tells me, but when he comments on the shirt, i cut him off.

"It's okay," I say, "At least it fits. So other than your sister, you have any family around here?"

He doesn't say a word as he puts large can of food onto the shelf. He stares at the can, as if reminded of something. What does he tell me?

Noah takes a deep breath and stands up straight and removes himself from the pantry. He walks over to the counter where I'm leaning against and leans against the space next to me. He takes another deep breath and begins explaining to me his family situation. "My mom, she died when I was in high school," he starts. "My dad took it the hardest and drove him to alcohol. Fortunately, my grandpa adopted us, stayed with him until I was 21." He pauses and in the silence, I dare not mess with the mood and say anything that could break his current reverie. He pushes himself off the counter and walks over to a box that he had recently put down near the stove.

He opens the box's flaps and proceeds to take out its contents, sets of dinner plates taped together for security. As he sets them down on the now empty counter, I pick this moment to ask him, "You mentioned you had your own place?"

He takes another deep breath, one out of relief rather than anticipation. It's as if telling me his life story was a sort of release.
