He pulls me off his lips to speak and I'm left with a compromised look on my face. "I forgive you though. It seems your beautiful body remembers our anniversary, remember our honeymoon last year." I quietly go for his tie and with no warning, undo it.

What does this husband of mine do?
1312.title: Suit and Tie

choices: A man
A woman
A nonhuman
132.content:
I come out of what could have been a brief slumber or something longer than brief. Be it a power nap or a good eight hours, I feel rejuvenated from my earlier state, which I somehow no longer remember. My old self, my memories, any recollection of event prior to a certain change I remember (through which I don't know) is nonexistent in my memory. All I know for sure is that I was a man before and now I'm a woman.

What distracts me from my reverie of what I used to be and what I am now is a movement across my naked female body. It's a hand, the actual size of it I'm not quite sure. The hand glides across the front of my torso and nestles itself in the valley between my breasts. The arm connected to it rests on my stomach and my side and I feel like I'm a life-sized teddy bear with no fur, only flesh. This unfamiliar presence, which is weight right behind me as I lay on my side in this bed is not at all uncomfortable. It's rather pleasurable to say the least. With its warmth added with the heavy blanket that cover the both of us, plus the soft and firm qualities of the mattress below us and the pillows underneath our heads, I can honestly say, I can stay like this forever.

This is when I feel some differences. It's when it restlessly moves about, I can tell what this presence is that is embracing me.

Who is this presence in bed with me?
132.title: Two in the Bed

choices: My hands are handcuffed behind me
A baby starts to cry
A doomsday siren starts going off
1321.content:
It's a man, I'm sure of it. I can tell that he's much bigger than me, since I'm now smaller, maybe even petite. As I start to be more wakeful and regain more of my body. I start to notice more. The arms of the man behind me is toned, if not muscular. His embrace is so tight, it's pleasurable and comfortable. Though I'm the one naked, the man isn't, for I feel poking at my booty is his semi-hard member tenting through a pair of boxer briefs.

The man's face comes over my shoulder and his facial hair, soft and ticklish on my skin, touches me as he closes in for a kiss. He rolls over, which in turn, he does the same, rolling me over onto my back, though my head cradle with his firm arm. This is when the surprise comes in and I notice...?

It's not a regular wakeful time like a morning or after an afternoon nap after afternoon fucking. We're not regular lovers, not from the things I notice. What is different?
1321.title: Opposite

choices: A younger man, possibly mid- to late-twenties dressed in a military BDU
A masked humanoid with two sets of arms
13213.content:
Comfortably, I roll over so that I'm now facing the man who's supporting my head with his arm. That's when I notice a scar on his bicep that runs from his elbow to his collarbone. Along his arm is what looks like tattoos of military origins and the scar disturbs all of them. Where ink would be is just scarred tissue now.

That's when the siren goes off. At first, it's low and seems to be far away, but after a few seconds the sirens do another round and it seems this time, the siren is right outside the window. I look up at the man and suddenly his eyes widen and like his instinct, glances at me, catching me watching him. "You're awake already?" the man says. His voice is rough, but for some reason, it doesn't bother me. "Anyway we have to go." He pushes himself up and I find that he does it like it's a struggle, despite his body being very fit and muscular. I lift my head so that he can have his arm back.

That's when I speak, asking, "Wait, what's going on? What's the siren for?"

Unusually, he finds the questions horrifying. "No, not you too!" I sit up in the bed with a puzzled expression on my face all while covering myself with the blanket.

A radio is heard coming from a satchel placed on the side table. The man goes for it, pulling out a walkie-talkie. He turns up the volume dial and a voice is heard from it. "Briggs! Come in! Bogeys sighted in Rift One-Niner-Theta. Get yourself and Sierra to bunker 16!"

"No go, Wedge. Sierra just woke with symptoms of AMNI. I'm going without her. Get a tech over here to escort her to Central!" the man says. I'm guessing his name is Briggs and my name is Sierra, though they could possibly be callsigns. The man efficiently dons a BDU in Atacs camouflage from the floor and puts the walkie-talkie back into his satchel. From the corner of the room near the bathroom door and the door to the rest of the house, he pulls out a case, shaped like it could store a gun. He opens it and takes out a gun with a bullpup style that I haven't seen before. He puts the case away and turns to me. "Stay here, whoever you are. Somebody will come and escort you to a safe place before---" he tells me, but an ominous boom from outside interrupts him. He doesn't give me another look and just exits the room.

Seeing this as my chance to get some answers, I get out of bed, unashamed that I'm currently naked in the room and go to the window. I pull aside the curtain to see a rather apocalyptic scene before me. I'm in a house that is within what looks to be a town or isolated community of residences, both houses and apartments. What makes the landscape different is the many sentry towers as well as dome-like structures that are foundations for massive cannons, which are targeted towards the sky. The nearest one is several years from what looks to be the house's backyard. This is when I see Briggs, the man I found in the bed with me, dashing for the bunker, which has a faded number of 16 on the side. In an instant, a ball of blue fire emerges from the thin fog and lands in the very area where I saw Briggs running. For some reason, a tear falls from my eye and I do not attempt to wipe it from my cheek.

The ensuing explosion is bright and almost blinds me and I step back, reeling from the light. This is when somebody from behind pulls me back and throws me on the bed, onto my back. I look up and see a gun trained at my face and I instinctively freeze. Who is it that has pinned me down?
13213.title: Briggs and Bunker 16

choices: Three women who seems familiar to me
No one
132131.content:
I look at the eyes of younger man dressed not in ATACS camo, but of a grey digital camo, much like Army BDU. On my forehead, he has trained a somewhat smaller version of the gun Briggs was carrying when he left the room. He stares into my eyes as if I'm an alien, like I'm part of a race that caused that ball of blue light to rain down from the sky.

"Diego!" an older voice shouts from elsewhere in the house. I hear boots stomping in the house, but I dare not look at the door when the other man enters. "How's Sierra looking?"

"She's fine. Clear sign of AMNI, stage three perhaps," the young man says. "Should we trank her?"

"I don't see why not," the older man says. "She's naked and I'm pretty sure she's going to take a long time to get dressed and put makeup on." He chuckles at the last part of is sentence. "The sooner you trank her, the better and then you can just carry her to central seeing Hiddenbrooke is on alert."

"Alright. Sierra, you need to go to sleep now. See you when you wake up," the man says and points the end of his gun on my arm and presses a button on the under-barrel attachment, which sends a stinging pain all along my arm that causes me to fall into a slumber.

When I come to, I wake up, clothed in a white tank top and short shorts. I lay in the middle of a white padded room, looking up at...?

Who do I see when I wake up?
132131.title: Sierra and Central

choices: The younger man takes each of us individually
We are taken as a group, with me and the black woman going with the older man
1321311.content:
When the drug that was injected wears off and I can finally get control of my body, I immediately notice that I'm no longer naked. The next thing I notice is the floor underneath me. It's similar to a wrestling mat with the right amount of firmness and the right amount of softness. I open my eyes to see a black woman with a long ponytail looking down at me. "She's awake!" she says and looks over at two other girls seated against padded walls. One looks like she's Caucasian and shortest in stature and the other looks Hispanic. For some reason, they look familiar to me.

I push myself up and the black girl assists me to a sitting position. "What's going on?" I ask. Beyond the walls, all I hear is low boom which could be explosions.

"Just another raid. At least, they tell us it's a raid. The five of us are here because we were found with symptom of AMNI, which is just another way of saying we have amnesia and can't remember any event before today," the black girl explains.

At the mention of five persons, I look for the fifth. A deep female voice speaks right behind me, alerting me to the fifth's presence. "They're going to sit us down, one-on-one to figure out what we know," she says. Her phrasing is a bit unusual and it seems she means is 'what we 'remember.' Her next phrase tells us otherwise. "We don't have amnesia. We are not the people people say we are. I, to be honest, am from the Rift!"

Suddenly, the door on the wall in the direction I'm currently facing bursts open, and in comes men dressed in uniforms of various camouflages, with vests of various shapes and sizes, with guns of that bullpup futuristic look. They all come in and point their guns towards my direction and without warning, pull their triggers. The expected bang from the guns isn't heard and instead, all I hear is somewhat like projectiles flying fast through air. Fortunately, I'm not hit by anything, though I do feel the air being displaced around me. When the dust settles, or in this case, when the chaos dies, we find the woman spouting nonsense behind me has been shot with hook like projectiles which seem to stun her into submission, leaving her writing on the padded floor.

The four of us left unscathed allow the men to approach and carry the woman out of the room. This is when I see the young man from before, the one who injected me with something to make me sleep. He allows the men to leave, save for one other man, who looks to be twice his age. What does he do?
1321311.title: Tyrone, Ricky and Sonny

choices: He takes Ricky, the Hispanic girl
He doesn't take anyone. He talks with us in the room
13213111.content:
"Sorry about that ladies," the younger man apologizes. "We had to take an extra precaution since all five of you were showing symptoms of AMNI, though the four of you did not show violent tendencies or nonsensical outbursts. She was stage 2. All of you are stage 1. We still need take each of you individually to find out what you know or what you can recall starting with you." He points to the Caucasian girl, who the Hispanic girl assures her with a gentle hand on her shoulder.

The girl, who I attach the name Sonny to, reluctantly gets up and approaches the two men. The older man opens the door, allowing the other two to exit the room. When the door shuts, the three of us left huddle together and start asking the needed questions.

I start by asking, "This may seem weird to ask, but do you associate yourself with the name Ricky?" Ricky is the name I attach to the Hispanic girl. "And you, Tyrone?" I attach Tyrone to the black girl.

"And the name I have for you is Cesar?" the black girl asks.

Nothing can hide the surprise on my face, but it sure does hide the disappointment I discover in not knowing anything else but their names. "And that one girl, the name I think was Sonny," I add.

"That's it," the Hispanic girl says. "Say, do you remember anything about being here?"

"Nothing. I just woke up in bed with a guy and then the sirens went off," the black woman says.

"Same thing for me," I say.

All of a sudden, the door to the room opens and in comes Sonny, the short Caucasian girl. The younger man allows her to meet up with us, but follows her to take....?

Which of the three girls left does he take?
13213111.title: One on One

choices: He is talking and directing his order to me
He is talking and directing his order to the black girl, who is called Tyrone
132131112.content:
Sonny comes running, though not as if in a hurry, back over to where we are seated. Assuming the younger man is here to take another us for a talk, I get to my feet and close the distance between him and me.

He instead raises his hand, stopping me in my tracks, saying, "No. You can sit down. I'd like to talk with all of you instead of alone." I stand there for a moment, as if he had blew me off, before retreating back to my seat. "The talk this girl and I had was very short, but revealed to me something unusual. Now, there is a name attached to all of you and to this girl, it seems she won't call you by any other name.

"Your name is Ricky," he says to the Hispanic girl, immediately garnering her surprise attention. "Yours is along the line of Tyrone?" he asks the black girl, who silently nods in agreement. "And this girl, Sonny, which is the name she calls herself, says your name is something like Cesar." I modestly agree by nodding as well.

"That's unusual and highly improbably," the older man says in his deep voice.

"Perhaps none of you know anything about the Rifts?" the younger man asks. In unison, we shake our heads. "Alright. Let's do it this way. Why don't you come with me?"

Who is the younger man talking to?
132131112.title: Sitting Us Down

choices: We go back right away
I have one more question
1321311121.content:
I see him directly into my eyes and his hand beckons for me. I look around and find everyone, including the older man is looking at me. I get to my feet and follow the younger man, who holds the door for me and closes it after her goes through the doorway. I enter a hallway that looks like the underbelly of a stadium. I turn around and see the younger man lean himself on the wall nearest the door. I just stand where I stop walking, my hands wrenching themselves in front of me.

"You say you call yourself Cesar. Any reason why you have a man's name?" he asks.

My face must have showed that I'm just as stumped as he is, for I respond, saying, "No clue."

"And you know nothing about what we call Rifts?" he continues with the questions. I shake my head, choosing to keep my mouth shut. "Well, I don't know if you know the times, but seeing you have symptoms of AMNI, I guess I should fill you in on what it's all about. The first sign of AMNI was actually a violent case. We were attacked by the force that occasionally raids the surface by the first recorded Rift. You could say it was the opening of a black hole that swallowed half the moon and sent the rest crashing down on the planet. We don't know what caused it, but ever since they started showing up, a portion of the population were stricken by bouts of amnesia. Entire days to even whole lifetimes of memories were lost and in ten percent of those that had AMNI, memories were replaced with violent visions that caused some of us to turn on our fellow humans. Much like that one woman we took out."

"Do you have a reason for the ... Rifts?" I ask during his pause from speaking.

"There are theories. We try to capture prisoners from the beings who attack us, but seeing we have no ways of communicating with them, efforts to gain intel are useless. Most are just crazed aliens willing to kill themselves in order to kill many others," he explains what I would call a professional answer.

"Who do you think?" I ask again, emphasizing 'you.'

The man looks at me, lifting his head as if my answer was a relief of the stressful day he must have had. He pushes himself off the wall and points his hand toward the door on the opposite wall. I look over and see it. He goes over and opens the door, politely letting me enter first into the dimly lit room. He flips a switch, which turns on rows of lights in what looks like an observation deck. As the lights finish turning on, the windows open up as well, as reinforced blinds lift up to show the exterior. The deck is situated on a ridge that overlooks the village as well as the towers and bunkers. All is calm and there is no attack at the moment.

My feet seem to move on their own volition and lead me to a bench situated at the end of the room, near the middle section of windows. I take a seat and sense the man following me, taking a seat on the opposite end of the bench. He finally answers my question. "I can think of nothing that would have caused these alien to start attacking us. They are not to blame. My reasoning is that we are the ones to blame, but we don't know for what reason. Whatever happened, it was the Rifts that brought them here. They must be the reason who people are getting AMNI nowadays." He pauses, getting up to look out one of the windows. He turns and lean on the window sill. "If you don't remember being Sierra or who she was to Briggs, then what do you remember? You said you named yourself Cesar. How would that be?"

"Well," I start, pausing just to attempt to recall anything. "I guess you can say I was a man in my past life, named Cesar. The other girls were probably my friends, that's why we call ourselves by those names we have. I think..." I trail off, attempting to think and recall any kind of memory in my brain. This has me getting up and walking over to very window sill the man is leaning against. I look out the window and suddenly a vision flashes before my eyes. "Did you see that?"

"See what?" the man asks, alerted. "What did you see?"

"A glove," I simply say, my eyes still close as I meditate on the vision.

"What kind of glove?" the man asks, keeping the line of communication.

"It looks like a regular glove, like those used for baseball," I explain and begin to see a scene materialize itself in my mind. "I see... a living room... hardwood floors... a swimming pool outside... Sonny, Ricky, and Tyrone was there. Sonny was always the short guy, Ricky our go-to Hispanic dude and Tyrone the mastermind. Tyrone had the glove on his hand.... he slapped Sonny and his fat was replaced by a muscular toned body. He slapped me next. I think it was me who requested him to turn me into a woman."

"Wait," the man speaks up. "This glove. By what you are saying, it somehow took something away, leaving behind a result. What did Tyrone say? Did he utter a command or something?"

"He did. To take away Sonny's fat figure, I think he said he would slap the fat out of Sonny. When he took away my male self, I think he said he was slapping the man out of me," I explain, the words and audio from the scene somehow being given to me by some unknown force.

"I think we have the answer now, but we have to verify it with your friends," the man tells me.

Do we go back right away or is there something else that needs to be said?
1321311121.title: Questions and Answers

choices: In a high school
At the supermarket
In a tropical jungle
133.content:
The moment I open my eyes, I feel sore all over, like I just did an intense workout in ten minutes. Most of all, my head hurts, making me wince. I attempt to open my eyes wide, but the pain in unbearable. Fortunately, gentle hand support my head and lift it from what seems like a hard floor. Did I hit my head upon it? Is that why it hurts so much. The gentle hands has given me enough comfort to encourage me to open my eyes again.

When I do, I force myself to keep them open and as a reward, before me is a handsome, attractive man. I wouldn't think so if I was man, but for some reason, I don't even remember anything before waking up. I have a vague recollection that I was male and through some unknown way, I'm currently the woman I am today. Whatever it may be, it's not as important as the man staring down at me. He's young, but not too young and neither is he too old. He speaks, but no sound is uttered from his mouth. A pain in my left temple causes me to wince again and close my eyes as well. I lift my hand to put pressure on it and fortunately it relieves it.

When I open my eyes again, I can now hear with my ears the voices around me. The atmosphere is loud and I can barely hear the people talking to me.

"Honey, are you okay?" a black girl says to me.

"You took a hard fall, there, Miss," the man says to me. "We'll need to put you someplace more comfortable to rest." Without any warning, the man lifts my small frame into his arms and for the first time, I can see my surroundings.

Where am I exactly?
133.title: I, the Damsel

choices: Break time, about two class periods over
Lunch time, after four class periods are over
At the ringing of the bell at the end of the school day
1331.content:
Once I'm off the ground and in his arms, I somehow feel embarrassed to be carried in the arms of a member of the opposite sex. Could it be me or the hormones? Anyways, what's more important is the place I'm currently in right now. No longer am I in a house and for some reason I have a vague recollection of a bungalow. I have yet to recall if I lived there alone or if somehow my male persona lived there. I'm not longer in that place. Now I'm being carried down a hallway of a school. The hallways are packed with boys and girls and from the look of their faces, I can tell I'm in a high school. And it's a public one too. No matching uniforms. Everyone is allowed to wear their own particular style.

For me, I'm wearing skinny pants of tan khaki fabric, with black sneakers on my feet. On my torso is either a blouse or baggy T-shirt. I'm not exactly sure. It seems to fit me, but the neck of the garment seems to be bigger than an actual shirt. Before I can deduce what it exactly is, we turn a corner and I look up at a sign, wincing a bit due to the sunlight entering the large windows, and give a slight sigh of relief. The destination was for the nurse's office.

The black girl from earlier comes into view and opens the door for us and the guy carrying me carries me in. We find the immediate area, which houses a wall with files cabinets lining every inch of it while on the opposite wall, chairs line every inch of it. A desk sits sort of in the middle of the room, with two arm chairs in front of it. Opposite the door we came into is another door, probably to the back room, where the beds are kept.

"Nurse!" the black girl calls out.

Immediately the Nurse comes out from the back room, a roll of bandages in her hand. She at once sees me and judging by her expression, I assume she thinks my ailment or whatever got me her int he first place is a terrible one. "Oh, come in and put her on a bed, but just put her on a bed. You can't stay," the nurses says.

"But we're her---" the black girl protests, but is quickly shut down by the nurse. In the meantime, the guy places me on the nearest bed and the mattress and pillow immediately give me comfort. The soreness and the pain in my head causes me to close my eyes

"Yes, I know. Classmates. Friends. Family even. But you'll have time to visit her during break. I'll need you two to run off to class now," the nurse says with confident authority. I don't remember anything else she says due to myself passing out due to fatigue and pain.

When I come to, what time of the day is it?
1331.title: Back To School

choices: A boy with a tough exterior
A girl with a conceited personality
13312.content:
I rudely wake up to the sound of a monotone sound of a bell ringing through the speakers of the school. The bell is so long that I can't help but get up in bed and look up at the clock which hangs in front of the speaker. The time is close to noon, obviously the bell is probably the signal that lunch has started. After the bell has finished ringing, I can hear the bustling sounds of students in the halls.

Immediately in the room, I can hear the nurse with another student and I turn my head to see....?

What kind of student is talking with the nurse?
13312.title: Lunchtime

choices: He tries to pull his arm free, pulling me with it and causing an accident
He politely asks for me to let go
133121.content:
When I sit up and look towards where the voices are coming from, I see a boy, who looks a bit older than a senior, sitting on a bed on the far wall. The nurse sits with him on the bed. From what I can hear, the conversation seems to be personal, as if they know each other. The deviant part of my mind assumes they have a fling with each other, but that notion is thrown out the window when I hear the words 'Mom' and 'Dad' used honorably by the nurse.

The nurse looks up and sees me watching them from my bed and immediately wipes the saddened look on her face and gets up to go over to me. "Hey, how are you doing?" she asks.

"I'm doing okay, I guess," I say with my gentle female voice. Somehow this is new to me, having never heard my voice like this. I hide the fact that I don't recollect anything other than the fact that I'm a girl who had an accident.

"I think you fainted when you came to class. Do you remember eating breakfast or drinking anything before coming to school?"

This is the time when I disclose my amnesia to the nurse. "Actually, I don't remember how I came to school. I actually don't remember where I live or where this school is," I explain.

"A bit of amnesia then. It's weird, there had been three other cases like yours. All of them girls like you. It's strange, but that girl that brought you in, she was one of those cases. She doing fine and seems to remember everything now. Maybe it'll be the same for you," she reassures me. Seconds after she finishes her sentence, the boy in the back gets up and tries to walk past the nurse. The nurse notices his escape and grabs him by the arm. I notice his fists, both of them being bandaged; the one of the right having patch of blood soaking through the white fabric. "Where do you think you're going? If you're going out to get lunch, then you're leaving school." The nurse gets up and escorts the boy back to his bed in the back. As she does so, she continues to talk to him, loud enough that I can hear. "You need to rest to heal your knuckles. You'll know what Mom and Dad will do when they hear about your recklessness."

Surprisingly, the boy only glares at her and abruptly turns his head away.

The nurse breathes out a sigh and comes back to my bed. She apologizes, "Sorry about that. That's my little brother. He flunked his senior year and has to take it again. He came in while you were out due to a fight during passing period. But enough about him, are you hungry?"

"A bit, yeah," I tell the truth. It seems the level of hunger I have is due to myself not having breakfast before coming to school and spending four periods of class without a bite to eat.

"You know what. I'm going to leave campus to buy the three of us food. Can you help me with my brother? He tends to break out of this room like it's a prison," she tells me.

I visibly gulp a bit of saliva and glance at the tough exterior and bloodied fists of the boy at the back of the room. "Okay," I say with little confidence.

"Don't worry. He's more rougher the guys than the girls, just make sure he doesn't leave your sight, okay?" she asks to which I give a nervous nod. Her smile when she leaves the room seems to reassure me though.

I listen and hear the nurse leaving the office, closing the door behind her. This is when, as expected, the nurse's brother gets up and goes for the door. Obeying the nurse, I reach out for his arm and successfully stop him in his tracks. What do he do next?
133121.title: The Brother

choices: In a bungalow in a cul-de-sac
In an apartment
1331211.content:
At first, he tries to gently yank his arm free of my grip, but my hand is like a vice on his forearm. He tries harder to no avail. It's when I pull him towards the bed when he loses control and accidentally pulls too hard, taking me with his arm. I lose my balance (mostly due to no food in my stomach) and in a sudden move, I send up falling to the floor with my head hitting the leg of the bed hard. I'm knocked out cold and enter a dark, yet brief slumber.

When I come to, I find myself in the bed again, a cool ice pack wrapped in a face towel on my forehead. "Rise and shine, girl," the voice of the nurse says. I open my eyes to find the nurse sitting on the side of the bed, smiling down on me. I look across to the opposite bed and find the nurse's brother fast asleep with his back facing us. "Don't mind him. He sometimes loses control when he doesn't get his own way. You've slept for a long while there. It's clearly an hour past the end of school. Can I ask, do you know where you live?"

I try to recall, but somehow there is a block preventing me to getting a single memory. Just trying to get past the block causes my head to hurt and I wince.

"Oh, oh, don't worry. This has happened before. As your guardian for now, I think it'll be best if you stay with me. No one has asked for you since school ended, so I'm guessing your parents don't pick you up from school and the best assumption is that you walk to school. I'll have to get your file and make sure you know who you are. In the meantime, you'll have to stay at my place, unfortunately, he'll be there too." The nurse points to the boy on the other bed. "I hope you don't mind."

"Not at all," I say.

"Shall we?" the nurse says, getting up and urging me up my feet as well. He goes over to her brother and slap him across the back of his head. "Hey, kid, this ain't your room. Get up! We're going home." The boy angrily wakes up, but once he sees me in my wakeful state, he dials down and apologetically bows his head toward me. The nurse slaps the boy again while saying, "You're supposed to say you're sorry, kid!" I smile and giggle a bit at the scene.

The nurse escorts us out of the schools grounds, where I see where the school is located. It's on top of a hill overlooking a beautiful city. Far away, near what looks like a harbor or bay, is the downtown commercial area. In between the hillside school and commercial district is green residential area. I get into the nurse's car and she drives us down the hill and down some streets to....?

Where does the nurse live?
1331211.title: Accident Prone

choices: Take pity on him and let him go
Be relentless and keep my grip on him
1331212.content:
"What the fuck are you doing?" he rudely asks as he gently tugs his arm in order to get free from my grip. My grip is actually tight and when he tugs a second time, I clinch down, further annoying him. "Can you please let me go?"

"Your sister told you to stay and since you want to leave, I have to make sure you do," I tell him confidently.

"Screw my sister. Screw this school! It didn't care about me last year. Who says it's going to care about me this?!" he protests. "Can you please let me go?"

"Why should I? Where are you going to go?" he asks.

"I'm going to get my own lunch, that's all and someplace where people know my name and care for me!" he explains.

What should I do?
1331212.title: Roughly Polite

choices: Lie
Tell the truth
13312122.content:
"Your sister seems to care for you very much!" I tell him, tightening my grip on his arm as much as I can. He pulls and easily lifts me from the bed and onto my feet.

"Let me go!" he exclaims, pulling me towards the door. Me having no shoes on means no friction and no way I'm going to keep this brute of a guy in this room. He easily inches me towards the door where he gives a final shake to loosen my grip. He shakes again and the sweat from my palms lubricates the contact and my hands slide from his elbow to his hand. He shakes one final time and I'm sent dropping to the floor, hard on my tail bone, striking a nerve, leaving me reeling with my knees to my stomach on the floor.

The nurse barges into the door and exclaims, "What's happening!?" She sees me on the floor, unresponsive and in pain and sees her brother confused of what is happening. Seeing her opportunity, she grabs her brother by the ear, wrenching it and causing him to groan loudly. "You little shit! I'm gone five minutes and then I come back to see that you're starting to hurt girls!"

"She fell, sis! It wasn't my fault," he becomes defensive.

"Yeah, right! Like you didn't that one kid!" the nurse shoots back before kneeling down before me and helping me up.

This could be my chance to get back at him. Should I lie and say he pushed me or should I accept my fault and humbly tell the truth?
13312122.title: Relentless

choices: The principal
Someone who calls herself my mom
133121222.content:
"He's right. I fell. I tried to grab onto him, but my hands slip and I fell," I tell the truth.

"But you're okay, right? Nothing broken?" the nurse says.

"Just a little bit of pain in my ass, but nothing is broken," I assure her.

"See? I told you it wasn't me," the nurse's brother says.

The nurse quickly shoots back, "That doesn't excuse your trying to get out of here, kid."

We are all struck silent when the door to the office opens and the person that opens it peeking into the room. Who is our visitor?
133121222.title: My Fault

choices: He found my file in the school's record
He asks about my opinion of the nurse's brother
Whatever it is, he wants me to come with him to his office
1331212221.content:
"Mr. Dean!" the nurse exclaims.

"Sorry if I scared you. I was just wondering what all the ruckus was about," the man says as he enters. He is a particularly young, old kind of guy. His hair is not that vibrant with color, yet it isn't bleach with white either. Here and there are patches of white or graying hair and his face seems to have a bit of aging involved. I could say he could be at least 50 years old, maybe 60 as well. "Mr. Samuels. How's your second run of senior year going? Staying out of trouble?"

"Of course, old man," the boy says. He manages to loosen his sister's grip on his arm and escape, darting for the open door.

The nurse tries to follow, but is stopped by the older gentleman. "Let him be. What are the odds that he's going to go missing? Time and time again, he always seems to find his way back home," he assures her with a gentle voice.

"His coming home in the end is not what worries me," the nurse says.

"Gwen, when's the last time you relaxed? Why don't you take a break while I have a talk with your patient here," he suggests, patting the nurse's shoulder assuredly. "I don't think I've introduced myself. I'm the school's principal, Mr. Victor Dean. And you are?"

I don't have the ability to recall the even simply thing of a name so I respond by saying, "I don't know."

"Hmm, Gwen did say you fainted early this morning and you showed signs of amnesia. She says the issue is only minor and you'll regain your memories soon. But I did wanted to talk to you about something," he replies.

What does he want to talk to me about?
1331212221.title: Mr. Dean

choices: He wants me to keep an eye over Nurse Samuel's brother
He wants me to investigate the strange occurances in the school
13312122211.content:
"I ran into Nurse Samuels and she told me you were in the infirmary, but she didn't know who you were. In fact, no one save a few students knew who you were," Mr. Dean tells me. "This led me to believe you were a new or transfer student. So I looked in the school records and indeed you do have a file." He pats a blue folder that I honestly did not notice until he gestured it with his hand. He picks it up and opens it and begins to read the more important parts of the file.

"Your name is Rosario Vega, but you like to be called Rosa," he reads and as he utters the words, I begin to remember actually writing that part down under a section titled 'Nickname.' "You're a transfer student that has transferred from a prestigious private school which isn't included due to some unknown reason. Hmm. Anyways, it seems you already completed half of your senior year at your previous school, but due to some reason, your credits couldn't be transferred. Must because of a curriculum error or it's just the difference. Here, you can have a look at that."

I take the form, which is a registration form that is neatly typed up. Indeed my name is Rosario Vega with the added nickname of Rosa. I'm already 18 years old as seen on the birth date section. I remember seeing the current date on a calender with past days already marked off.

"Your parents are currently overseas and have authorized a certain sum of their income for your schooling and extracurricular needs. I have seen to it that you were put into a dorm with three of our other transfer students a bit of distance from the school. As principal, seeing your record, I requested that you have special privileges as something like a class president. Over the years, our school has been plagued with confrontations with other students from other schools. Let me tell it to you straight," he explains, then pauses before telling me, "You were transferred here to this school, not to be a student, but to be a help to the staff and faculty. It seems the staff and faculty are having a difficult time connecting with the students, so we need students in order to relay our concerns to them."

Mr. Dean gives me the rest of the envelope and after reading everything that seemed interesting, I breath a sigh of stress.

"It's a lot to take in, but I hope you'd stay with the school and help us out. I believe there were incentives that were to be given once signs of progress are made aware amongst the staff and students. And, if it's not too much to ask, I'd like you to personally....?

What extra thing does Mr. Dean want me to do?
13312122211.title: Identity Reveal

choices: I invite her into the dorm
I tell her what the principal told me
133121222111.content:
"I'd like you to personally keep an eye on Shane Samuels, the boy who just left," Mr. Dean adds. I show my shock on my face, but before I can protest politely, he defends his order. "Before you can say anything, I just want to say that you being transferred to this school had a purpose. The purpose was to clean up this school with strategies and views from a different perspective. I don't know how it was in the school you attended in the past, but I'd like to gather your thoughts so that this school can become prominent again. And it should start with Mr. Samuels. He's this close to being a high school dropout, picking fights with underclassmen and being an outright bully to everyone else. You might know by now that he has to retake his senior year due to insufficient credits. I'd like you to watch him and make sure he stays in school and not out in the world where he so wants to be. Do you think you can do that?"

"Just watch him?" I ask after finally being able to speak. "That's it?"

"For the most part, yes, but there could be times where you have to be hands-on. Just don't let it come to that if you prefer to be hands-off," the principal assures me. I breath another sigh of my stress, but it in turn causes my stomach to rumble. "All this talking and I've kept you from lunch. Gwen, can you please come on in?"

"Right away, Sir," the nurse says. and gets up from her desk and enters the back room.

"Take the rest of the day off. And see to it that Miss Vega knows where the dorm is," the principal orders. He then turns to me. "Get some rest and get some food in you. I'll expect to see you two in the morning?"

I glance at the nurse and back at the principal. Without thinking, in unison, the nurse and I nod our heads in agreement. I gather the files into the folder and get up from the bed. Due to my weakness from having no food in my stomach, I sort of lose my balance. I would have fallen to the floor again if it weren't for the nurse's quick reflexes. "You must be starving there," the nurse mentions as she helps me get into a balanced position. "Come on, let's go. The sooner you get home, the sooner you'll get some food in your stomach."

The two of us leave in a hurry, leaving the school grounds and into the nurse's car in the faculty parking lot. She drives down the slopes driveway that connects the school to the main street below. The school is, after discovering the landscape around it, at the top of a hill overlooking the whole city where it resides. In the distance looks like a bay or coastline, where the city's downtown commercial district is located. Between that and the school are more residential areas and the height of the buildings shrink to just a few stories.

The drive to the dorm is pretty short by car and we find that a gate separates the complex where the dorm is located from the outside. The nurse presses a button which allows the door to slide away and give enough space for the car to drive through. I give a puzzled look, to which the nurse explains. "You know I used to live here when I was going to this school. My mom and dad used to leave on extended business trips, probably like your parents. I'm glad I still have this remote. It seems they didn't change the frequency."

The car enters and after giving the nurse the building number, she drives into the driveway.

This seems a lot for the nurse to do this for me. A token of my gratitude could be given. What kind of token of gratitude do I give the nurse?
133121222111.title: From A Distance

choices: The delinquent boy from before
Both the delinquent boy and the tall hall monitor
The nurse, now dressed in casual clothes
13312122213.content:
"What about?" I ask.

He looks around, to see if the coast is clear, and responds afterward. "Not here. When you're able, come to my office," he tells me and turns on his heel and walks out of the door. I take one step in front of the other and find that I'm not fatigued at all. Maybe a bit sore in places, but all in all, my mobility is fine. I skip to the door and find the foot of the principal take a right down the hallway. I follow him silently, walking down two flights of steps and several hallways before getting to what looks like the front of the school. I get within paces of the door that has "Principal Mr. Dean" engraved on the mostly-opaque glass when someone grabs me by the arm. I try to jerk my arm free, but the grip on my arm is too strong. I look and see that it's a student, awfully taller than me with the body of a runner. He has a band around his arm that vaguely says "Hall Monitor."

"What are you doing during class hours?" he aggressively asks.

"Let her go, Sinclair. I asked her to come to my office," the familiar voice of Mr. Dean is heard behind me. I turn around and see him standing in his doorway. "Come on, boy. What do I say on how to treat a lady?"

The tall boy named Sinclair (possibly his last name) lets me go at Mr. Dean's command and allows me to walk towards Mr. Dean. He enters his office while propping the door open for me to enter in.

"Take a seat," Mr. Dean says and gestures to a pristine leather chair in front of his desk. "Victor Dean is acid-engraved on a acrylic prism that sits in the very center of his desk. "What I want to inform you is that we do have a file for you. My secretary has gone through the trouble is retrieving it for me."

"So I'm a student at this school?" I ask.

"Transfer student in fact. The district allows a few to enroll due to various reasons," he tells me and opens a folder he has on his desk in front of him. "Your parents are overseas and has sent you to finish your last semester here at this school. Here, have a look." He closes the folder and hands it over to me. I place it down on the empty space on the desk right in front of me and open the folder. Once I see my mugshot, I get lightheaded all of a sudden. In a few painful seconds, all my memories return to me. I now remember my name, which is Jocelyn Bautista, and I'm a transfer student at this high school, finishing my last semester of my senior year. According to the file, which matches perfectly with my memories, I just transferred today and was on my way to my first class when I suffered a headache in one of the upper floor hallways. Through the flood of images and voices, I can hear Mr. Dean call out to me, "Miss Bautista, are you alright? Do I need to send for the nurse?"

I get a hold of myself, but only barely. In only a few seconds, I have remembered the more vivid moments though they are too many to count or list in one sitting. Even though I hear Mr. Dean, I don't respond. Calmly, without being alarmed, he gets up from his seat and rounds the desk. I can barely see through blurry eyes, but someone, which possibly could be the dean, gets me to my feet and walks me to the door. I only recall making it halfway up the first flight of stairs when my vision completely blurs to black.

I don't know how long I'm out but when I come to, I find myself back in the nurse's office, laying on the very same bed that I found myself on the first time. But I'm not alone and I can sense that there are people around me. Who is in the room with me?
13312122213.title: Dean's Office

choices: Against all rational thought, I choose to walk home with the delinquent boy
Impressed by T.J.'s offer, I choose to walk home with him
Boys!? Ewww! Much better with an older sister walking me home
133121222132.content:
I come to hearing what sounds like a finishing statement of what seems like a heated argument. The very voice that finishes sounds familiar too. "Don't you have someplace to be?" the voice says in contemptuous manner. The question isn't answered.

I push myself up to a sitting position and find myself on a bed which the nurse, now dressed in casual clothing, is sitting on. I look up at her and she gives me a warm smile. "A natural sleeping beauty. Isn't that twice I've found you sleeping on my beds?" she jokingly asks. "You must be wondering why I'm out of my scrubs. You, Miss Bautista, have slept through the dismissal bell. Most of the students have left already." As she says this, two boys walk around the corner of the office. The delinquent boy from before and the hall monitor that must have helped me back to the nurse's office. "Except for these two. So which one of you will do the honors and walk this young lady home?"

The delinquent drops his gaze and looks to the side, seemingly uninterested. The hall moniter, seeming to be more confident, steps up and volunteers himself. "As class president, it's my duty to see to the well-being of all student, no matter the gender," he says with a boisterous voice.

"Well said, T.J.," the nurse says, but immediately after, the delinquent boy scoffs at the both of them. I look at both expression of the nurse and the hall monitor T.J. and both seems pissed off at the attitude of the other boy, whose name I can't quite recall. "It's your choice Miss Bautista. If you're not too keen in going home with a boy escort, I can always take you. What do you say?"
133121222132.title: Rivals

choices: A man answers
No one answers, but the gate is opened by an incoming car.
No one answers the second time
1331212221322.content:
"I'll go with T.J.," I say, with a voice that clearly shows that I'm impressed by the class president's chivalrous act.

"Alright. Since Miss Bautista has a proper escort, you boy can escort your older sister home," the nurse says to the delinquent boy, who seems uninterested. "Almost forgot, here is your file to help with your memories and your pack. Tomorrow, I'd like to see you with your books for the rest of the year as well as you present in your classroom. i don't want to see you back in one of my beds, you hear?" I nod in understanding. She hands me my backpack and then the folder which I put into my backpack. I zip it tight and follow T.J out of the nurse's office.

Once in the hallway, I find T.J. looking back at me. He says to me, "I have to go to my locker and get my bag and other things. Meet me at the front? It's the glass doors down the hall from the Dean's office."

"Okay," I tell him and he then turns on his heel and hurries down the stairs. I follow him, but at a relaxed pace, down the same flight of stairs. I feel somehow ignorant of various things and I have an urge to know more things. Maybe its this bout of amnesia that is somehow hindering my self-awareness and my awareness of the world around me. I'm reminded of the folder in my backpack. I remove one strap of my backpack, which is colored in a two-tone color scheme of ocean blue over a sandy beige with black straps and fastening buckles. I open the larger pocket and pull out the folder. I put back the strap after zipping the pocket up and proceed to head to the entrance of the school.

Along the way, I take a look at the folder, opening it up and skimming through all pieces of information. I see my name again, saying it out loud so I know what my name is. "Jocelyn Bautista," I say and repeat it in my head. It sounds either Filipino or Hispanic. Maybe it could be a combination of the two. I would have to see myself in a mirror if I'm to know for sure. I then glance at transfer student and I'm reminded of what Mr. Dean told me. I was a transfer student who transferred during the winter break and I'm attending school for the last semester. That's two quarters of a year. At most, I have the last six months of school to finish, since I'm a senior. Boy, being a senior again, but in a whole different body. There's the whole thing with puberty and the monthly period as well, but I don't feel as bothered by it as I initially think it. What bothers me is any upcoming headaches.

Then as I'm nervous for it, it suddenly comes upon me. It hits my head first and I immediately close the folder and clutch it tight to my chest. One of my hands feels it through my sternum, beating wildly. I fall to my knees and I push myself against a hard place, the wall, but with a clang of metal, it's none other than a row of lockers. I put the folder down and with both my hands free, I clutch both to the side of my head, using the heel of my wrist to apply pressure in order to alleviate the pain. It does little to help me. I'm suddenly thrown into a vivid memory.

I hear the sound of a train running along its track. As it turns, the metal wheels grind against the metal of the rails. Wind rushes past the windows. I'm comforted by the cushion of a hard, vibrating surface. I find myself on the bench of what could be a subway car. I open my eyes and see light pouring into a clean subway car, but what's a subway doing where light can hit it and soak it in. I sit up and put earbuds into my ears and a loud acoustic version of the song Drive by Incubus fills my ear canals. I breathe in and out deeply. I remember a man's voice followed by a woman's voice. They are both endearing and loving. My eyes sheds tears, which turn into a silent deluge down my cheeks. I look up, seeing no one in the car. I wipe my eyes dry, able to see a sun rising behind an ocean. The ocean, reflecting the hue of the sunlight, illuminates what was previous shrouded in shadow. As the train crosses over a bridge, a coastal town starts to emerge. From what I can see, there is a commercial district, lining the coast, a city center, which also has a theme park incorporated into it, and a residential district more inland and what looks to be a whole school on a hill over looking rows of houses. I feel myself smile and then the memory fades away.

"Are you okay?" the familiar voice of T.J. asks. His voice alerts me to his presence and I look up to find him seated right next to me. He hands me a tissue which I gladly take due to my eyes feeling a bit watery. I must have started to cry as I was experiencing that memory. Somehow, it told me the voice of my father and mother were the last of what I could remember about them. Them sending me here to finish my schooling is still a mystery, but I know it wasn't done out of spite. "You didn't have another seizure did you?"

"Not really. It's just me remembering things," I say.

"What things?" T.J. presses.

I look at him with an expression of concern on his face. I understand that he is class president and it is his duty to see to my well-being, but him being nosy may be pushing it. "Things I remember," I vaguely tell him as I get to my feet. He offers to help, but I gesture him not to.

"So where do you live?" T.J. asks. Initially, I forget that he's my escort and assume that he's still being nosy, but seconds later, I forget that I have my file with me. I find it on the ground and pick it up, quickly opening it to find the address of where I'm staying.

"365 Skyline Drive... I think," I tell him.

"Skyline Drive?!" he exclaims with shock on his face. "Your folks must be rich or something." I don't answer since I'm also in shock, more on his reaction than the actual truth. My gut tells me that I wasn't too keen on people being rich or that money never bothered me enough to worry or greed for it. "I know where it is, but you need a code to get into the gates. It's one of those communities."

He turns on his heel and exits out of the door. I follow him closely. For much of the way, T.J. is busy navigating the streets which turn into a school zone immediately outside of the school, then becomes a combination of rural and suburban. I can say that there are a few rice paddies smack dab next to tram tracks and strawberry fields next to a busy thoroughfare. As I'm walking, I observe that the school is actually situated on a hill and kids must travel down a hill to get home. I figure it's a more of a relief than going to school from home. T.J. suddenly turns onto a street and suddenly the houses start getting bigger and fanciers. Heck, even cars on the street look more expensive than cars near the school. I'm bound to find a supercar or hypercar around here, no doubt.

T.J. turns onto another street, which winds up a hill. The street itself is not asphalt, but a light-orange brick. Flanking the street are pristine concrete sidewalks and immediately next to them are tall metal fences. Only a swift martial artist would be able to traverse up and over these fences. We eventually get to a gate. A key pad on a pole sits on the island in the center of what could be considered a roundabout. Another key pad sits next to a door knob of a pedestrian gate. A speaker sits next to the key pad. I guess this is how guests ring up the houses. Is there any need for door bells in this place.

"It's in there somewhere. Try dialing the house number, unless you know the code," T.J. suggests.

"I don't remember... remember?" I point out the obvious. i walk up to the door and press the numbers 3... 6... and 5 on the key pad. A dial tone rings and rings and rings and rings and rings for a last time immediately switching to a generic voicemail sort of automated message telling us that the occupant of this particular home is not able to answer the request and that it's suggested to try later.

"Try it again, maybe he... or she was in the bathroom or something," T.J. says.

I try it again, dialing the same numbers on the key pad. Does anyone answer?
1331212221322.title: Class President T.J.

choices: To a mall filled with a lot of people
To a inner-city shopping district
To his house of all places
13312122213223.content:
I wait for what seems like a minute and still, no one answers the buzzer. The tall black-painted gate with golden accents at the top of each bar does not move an inch.

"I guess no one's home to answer," T.J. suggests.

"So what do we do now--?" I start to ask, but for a brief second it feels like all of my blood rushes down from my brain and I teeter backwards. I expecto to hit the ground hard like the previous times, but instead, I'm caught in the arms of T.J., who eases my body to the ground.

"Are you okay?" he says as he props my head on his thigh.

I glance up at him and for some reason I get all nervous, like a girl and I sit up, but not without getting a pain that throbs all over my head. I groan, "Yeah."

"Are you sure? Cuz this is the third time this has happened on my watch," T.J. mentions. "Say, have you eaten anything today?" He walks around me as he asks this and he catches a certain expression on my face. "I guess not." He turns around as if he is mad at me and I try to think. In the times I've either had a flashback or blacked out, I don't recall ever eating anything. Not even a morsel. I'm lost in thought until T.J. puts a hand in front of me. It's open with his palm facing the sky. I look up at him and shoot him a inquisitive look. "You must probably be hungry. I can give you a piggy back ride to a place that's close."

I furrow my brows and say, "I can walk just fine."

"Not on an empty stomach. Come on," T.J. says, gesturing his hand in a beckoning motion. "As Class President, I cannot leave one of my fellow classmates here to starve."

I scoff at the idea, thinking it's inappropriate for me to be taking this ridiculous offer. He takes it further, turning around and squating. I get to my feet and look around. Someone probably is watching the two of us from the comfort of their window and wondering what a pair of high-schoolers are doing at a locked gate. How I wished someone pitied my situation and opened the door for me.

"Any day now," he says. At this moment I consider him too committed to his philosophy and outlook for his peers to even consider another option. "Or else I'll starve here with you." His last remark strike a guilty cord within me and it makes me step forward and place my hands on his shoulders as well as placing my body close to him.

In a quick movement, he rises and rears backward and successfully catches my thighs and holds them close to my side so that I'm sort of straddling him. My face warms up in embarrassment and since I'm a bit scared of how fast he moved, I scream for a brief second. His daring move almost knocks the breath out of me. And did I mention I sort of scared of heights? Since I'm sort of off balance as all my weight bears down on this guy, I clutch at the boy's shoulders and wraps my arms about him to further stabilize myself. This unwittingly presses my chest against his back.

"Shit," T.J. says. His voice drowns out any chaos that is thrashing in my head and I can calmly hear him speak.

"What?" I calmly ask him.

"If you're on my back, then where is my backpack?" he asks and I immediately forget about worrying that I'm on his back and I look around for his backpack.

"It's right there!" I say, point a bit to his right on a backpack that half on the grass and half in the black soil of a planter.

"Since my hands are full, I need you to reach for it. I'll squat down as far as I can and you just grab it and hold it," he tells me.

Before I can protest, he goes over and squats down. I reach for it, thinking he'll be too tired afterwards to keep me on his back. For the first try, I can barely reach it, since it sits flat on the ground and the handles being two or three inches away from me. T.J. dares himself and bends over, gravity unwittingly pressing my chest against his back, but due to his move, I can finally grab onto a handle and pull it up. I sling it over my shoulder and with one hand, I hang on for dear life, hoping T.J. will bring me down to the ground soon.

"Got it?" he asks, seemingly out of breath.

"Yeah," I tell him. He suddenly turns on his heel, straightens himself out as much as he can and starts walking down the slight incline to the hills. All I can do now is silently protest as I hang on for the unwanted ride.

Just where does T.J. take me?
13312122213223.title: No One Home

choices: A large mountain
A town situated on the hills
A large construction site
133121222132231.content:
T.J., once he gets back to the street we turned off from, turns the opposite direction we came from previously. The streets get more busy with more automobile and foot traffic. I duck my head to hide my face from passing pedestrians, half of which turn their heads to look at the two of us. I just hope they are not drawing conclusions. The conclusions I'd want them to come to is that me, the girl on his back, had drunk something very alcoholic, but I have my doubts that it wouldn't be the top contender with the obvious ones.

T.J. eventually crosses multiple streets all while on slight slopes. When apologizing about all the bumps I'm feeling, he says, "Sorry about that. This place is notorious for its hills."

Part of me is glad that I'm on his back, my legs especially relieved from bearing my weight. Part of me pities T.J. for having to carry more than his weight on his two legs. Part of me wants to shut up and enjoy the ride while the other part of me wants to apologize at every mile we go.

We eventually get to a huge plaza, dominated by a large multi-story building. Judging from all the young peoples amassed around the building, this place is a center for entertainment and socializing. T.J. continues on without letting me down and I grow more conscious of the two of us and the youthful-couple-vibe I get with all the potential watches around us. He carries me through an archway with small shops lining every side. At the end of this archway is an inner plaza, lit by the sunlight above a canopy with no ceiling. A large fountain sits in the very center of the plaza, which is flanked by the many windows of restaurants and shops lining the walls. The two of us enter into a glass elevator and this is where he lets me down.

Immediately, I'm concerned for the health of this boy, who had to carry additional weight for what it seemed to be more than five miles. Sweat has already formed on his forehead, which is wipes with his forearm and his breathing is heavy and deep, as if he had run a mile. "Are you okay? Sorry." I ask and immediately apologize.

"Don't be," he coolly says. "You are obviously starving and I did not want you to hurt yourself if you had another one of your blackouts." He turns around, takes his backpack from my arm and leans against the curvature of the glass window. An ounce of me thinks he looks cool. "The least you could do is enjoy the scenery."

I'm baffled at how cool his attitude is, almost carefree. I forgot I still have the mind of a mature male, whose persona and identity still continues to elude me. I look out the window and with an expressionless face, I see the wonder of this building. Unfortunately, the elevator ride is short and we get to what seems to be the highest level. I follow T.J. out the elevator door and onto a boardwalk like flooring.

The immediate area is like a boardwalk, one that wraps around the inner edge of the roof platform, that overlooks the inner plaza and large fountain below. Across from the elevator is an eating area. Many tables and chairs fill this place, which is draped with a cloth ceiling, providing much shade, but allow cool air to flow through the space.

I follow T.J. into the area and he sits me down at a table situated near the outer edge of the roof, overlooking the plaza. I look the side and see different colored tiles, which are red tiles within a blue outline against the gray cement. The tiles spell out "NORTH PLAZA." This must be the north side of the mall then. I look up above the city and find what looks like the school in the distance. Beyond that is much trees and rolling hills, but dominating them from above, is what?
133121222132231.title: Piggyback To The Mall

I wake up to find myself lying on my back on what seems like animal fur. Is it a bear rug or some other type of fur? I can't tell for sure, only that the feeling of it against my naked body is comfortable. And yes, immediately I note that I'm naked as well and in the woman's body I ask for. I guess the slap did something more than change me. It transported me, but where exactly, I'm not sure. Covering me is what seems like another hide blanket and the fur is less soft and more heat-trapping. Underneath my head and resting on my nape is a small, yet soft pillow.

I decide to open my eyes, but when I do, I see nothing. I discover that a blindfold or shroud covers my eyes and is so tightly secured that no matter what I do, I can't take it off. I try to remove myself from the bed of fur, but when I turn myself over, I find that tied around one of my ankles is a thin and slender rope, that like the blindfold is tightly secured. It's tied in such a way that if I struggle, it digs into my skin.

"It's no wonder your people have the inborn desire to escape control," a deep raspy voice is heard in front of me, beyond the pillow which my head once rested. "Which should explain the eradication of your kind by the Sovereignty."

"What do you mean?" I ask, wondering minutes afterward why I didn't ask for his name or what kind of circumstances led me to being bound by a rope and being naked in a bed.

"You've never heard the stories, girl?" the raspy voice asks. "Assassinations on assassins, son and daughters of assassins? Wiping you out like a plague."

"What are you talking about? Who are you? And why are you talking to me like that?" I ask, continuing to struggle and therefore tighten the rope around my ankle. For a long moment the voice doesn't utter a single word. It seems like an eternity passes by before I hear footsteps approach me and hands fiddling with the tied at the back of my head. The blindfold loosens, but what shocks me is that I cannot see, even without the blindfold. I try blinking back my vision by allowing whatever light to kickstart my sight, but nothing happens. I do see a purple haze in places, but all I see is white. I start to feel hands on my ankle and the rope that has began to dig into my skin. Once the rope has been untied, I recoil my leg and use it to sit up and desperately try to cover my nakedness, since a cold breeze passes across my chest and through my legs.

I can't really do much, since the man behind me grabs the top of my head and places a sharp blade to my throat. "I've freed you, but I'm not taking chances with a helpless Amaranthine," the raspy voice says in my ears. With my hands, I try to distance the blade from my throat, but unknowing cutting myself on the twin edge of the blade.

"Please sir, spare me. I don't know what's going on or what Amama-ran-teen is, please," I plead, letting my emotions get the better of me. I easily start to tear up knowing my life is in this man's hands.

He abruptly takes the blade from my throat and pushes me forward onto my stomach. The comfort of the soft fur tickles the tips of my breasts, but as soon as I feel the sensation, the next feeling I feel is pressure, for the man has pinned me to the ground with his knee. He forcefully takes the hand that had cut itself on his blade and begins wrapping it. "It's pronounced Amaranthine, fool," he says. "How can someone from a race of assassin not know how to pronounce their race? Unless... well.... well, we did find you on the riverbank. Say, girl, do you know your name?"

I pause, knowing the name I remember when I was a man, but stopping myself from uttering it due to the awkwardness that a man's name would be given to a woman. Instead of blurting out my previous name, I reply, "I had a name, but I don't remember or recall what it is. So the answer is no."

"An Amaranthine with no name?" the raspy voice asks, though I can tell it's not directed towards me. "What colors me confused is that our scouts found you soaked to the bone on the riverbank. They also noted you received a concussion, but to what extent we could not find out due to you being an Amaranthine."

"Sir. I don't mean to annoy you, but what is an Amaranthine," I ask, desperate for answers.

"I don't know the full history, but what I can tell you has been told over countless campfires, many of which were after deadly encounters with them," the raspy voice begins to explains and finally lets me get to a sitting position. I immediately take the hide blanket and use it to cover my front side. "They were a legendary race once employed by the Sovereignty. They were created, not bred. They were merely humans who were infused with science and the occult, rendering their blood to turn from red to deep purple, thus labeling you as the purple-blood, or Amaranthines, for when seeing your veins or bruises up close, the color would be a like the shade of night.

"They were incredible assassins, whose senses were heightened. They could hear from miles away, track deserters and exiles like blood hounds, and they could see through all spectrums of light, but most notably in the dark. After many days of peace, turmoil brewed between the Sovereignty and the races. For a while, your people were given territory to roam free, but with your inborn desire to conquer and with no targets to focus on, your people raids villages and townships on a nightly basis. That's when the Sovereignty decided to wipe out your clan. This is probably the same series of stories of male purple-bloods plundering and raping women and the women bore hybrids. The offspring still had the heighten senses, but they were blind at birth. But there was no differentiating between the two. The Sovereignty orders purebreds and half-breeds to be wipes out from the face of the Earth. Now it's rare to see an Amaranthine, but the history your people have and how they affected the land still stays. You probably wouldn't last out there if it weren't for us."

"So who are you?" I ask. I may look visibly relaxed after that story he just told.

"You must have drifted down the Allotrope River all the way to the border. We are but a small group of cavern dwellers who live between the mountains and the desert," the raspy voice says. "I'm Dezra, leader of the Goldmanes. And since you don't have a name, then I'll give you a choice. Either you can name yourself or you let me name you."

What should I choose?
1351.title: Amaranthine

choices: Dezra and an animal
Dezra and another person
A whole group of people
13513.content:
"Why don't you call her something that's not as menacing and malicious as a purebred Amaranthine? Why not something gentle?" a female voice speaks from beyond Dezra's position in the room. Since I deduce this room is in a cavern of sorts, the female voice may be coming from the room's entryway or a connecting Hallway. "She doesn't look like she'll hurt a fly."

"Forgive my sister. The broad doesn't know when to shut up and find a man and leave this band of brothers I have," Dezra says to me. "Don't you have some man-hunting to do?"

"I've found many men, brother, but it's your right to marry first. Why don't you bed that violet-blood right in front of you?" the woman says and I can hear her leave the room.

"Again, I must say, you'll have to forgive her. But for a name, I think I can call you Zephyra, which means a gentle western wind. You don't look like the type to lunge at me and put my knife to my throat, so the name should suit you," Dezra says. "Now that you have a name, I should probably ask how you ended up on that riverbank we found you at."

"I don't remember," I say. If I try to recall what led me to being put here, all I can see is cloudiness and fuzziness.

I hear Dezra get to his feet. It's weird. I can honestly hear everything in the room, especially where this nomad is walking. When I close my eyes, every time a sound is made, I can literally see the sound waves creating vague outlines of the rocky pillars that support the ceiling as well as Dezra and other furniture. When he speaks, my audible vision is much clearer and I can actually see the features of his face, even though it last for only a second. When absolutely no sound is made, when my eyes are closed, all I see is darkness.

"I was afraid you'd say that, Zephyra," Dezra speaks again after a brief pause. "We had heard of a raid on a mountain encampment of rogue Amaranthine. In a report, it was rumored that everyone including humans allied with the Amaranthines, children and pregnant mothers were killed. It was also rumored that a female Amaranthine hybrid had escaped only by falling as a purebred male by the name of Draine jumped in front of her to catch an incoming arrow meant for her. She survived it seems that her male purple-blood companion broke her fall as the two of them hit the water. What I'm thinking is that female hybrid is you. Do you feel anything when you hear the name Draine?"

"No, I don't," I simply say and with no hesitation.

"If that woman is you, Zephyra, then you must have hit your head and got amnesia from the trauma. In any case, you should be safe here. Our scouts have not reported any sign of the Sovereignty," Dezra tells me. "Since you are a hybrid, then it's likely you don't see anything--"

"I see when you talk or make a noise," I butt in to clarify.

"Well, you are no purebred, so you do need assistance. Do you remember how you life was before the raid?"

Again, I try to think and see if this body of mine, no matter how impaired, had any memory of some kind. Again, I fail to conjure up anything of this body's life. "Honestly, I don't remember being born nor do I know who my parents are," I reply.

"But you are ashamed of being unclothed. You might be no purebred, but you are still human," Dezra encourages. "For now, rest. I'll go see if your clothes are dry."

I hear Dezra leave the room and for the next ten minutes I wait and listen to see if he or anyone else enters the room. After eleven minutes of silence, I lay my head back down on the pillow and drift back to sleep.

When I wake up, I hear noises in the room. Who has entered the room?
