"Don't go all scientist on me now. Aren't we going eat? Are you going to deprive a woman of precious food?" I joke.

"Why would I, after everything else I provided?" he asks in a jokingly way. He steps forward and leading me out of the room and out into the hallway. As I walk, carefully with each step, I look around and observe the house around me. I can tell this man is well off, since judging by the room's size and proportionally the rest of the house, the whole building is rather large. At the end of the hallway, is an open room, which consists of a cylindrical clearing with a hole in the middle. To prevent anyone from falling into the hole, where a spiral staircase sits, a banister surrounds the edge of the hole. The man assists me as I pick up the front of my dress so I don't accidentally step on it as I walk down each step.

At the bottom, I'm greeted with a foyer, which itself is also cylindrical. The man walks me to the front door, which he opens, revealing his driveway. He leaves me on the top step of the porch as he goes to bring his car. The next time I see him, it's in a shiny convertible. He also has donned a new pair of glasses as well as his smile.

"I thought this wasn't a date," I mention.

"It's not," he calls out to me, "but how's a man to take a woman out if it's not in style." Seriously, even if he doesn't have the desire or intent, he really tries too hard to impress me. Though, it's hard not to show it on face.

If this was a date, he would get out of his car to open the door for me. I certainly know it's not a date, for he just watching me as I walk, on my own, down the steps and onto the driveway and into his car. Though it would have been nice to have a bit of help, with my heels and all, I have to remind myself that if this man helps me, I'm his woman. I am certainly not his woman. Just an equal. I make it to the car door and inside the car with no struggle.

He drive his car off his estate and along the way, I find out more about him. His name is Alan Murao, who runs his own clinic. He says he's a physician and does check ups as a majority of his work. On the side, he does the experimental work of transferring peoples' consciousness from one body to another. He did it as an investment from a generous investor, but he doesn't know who he is, which worries me.

Eventually, we get to the city and to the very building that the restaurant is in. We walk in and find that it's a hotel and a rather nice one too. We see other couple there, though with their hands interlocking each other. I try not to let the emotions of this body get to me, as seeing one is fine, but seeing multiple couples with the lovey-dovey signs of their relationships, it's hard not to get jealous. I remind myself, I'm here with a colleague and a friend, who I do not know that well yet. I'm not here on a date with a potential suitor. I wonder if this guy is asking himself the same thing.

We have to check in at the desk, but fortunately, this man has already made reservations with the restaurant. We enter an elevator alone and ride it to the top. What do we find at the top?
13533333111113113.title: More Higher

choices: Switch elevators
Go up one more floor and try to use the stairs to get to the penthouse
Go someplace else of my choosing
135333331111131133.content:
For about twenty floor or so from the bottom, we can see the lobby below us, but as the elevator rises higher, the ability to see the lobby stops. Alan directs my eyes behind me where we can see outside the building. The view of the city outside is much better than a luxurious lobby that has an high ceiling of twenty or so floors.

I look at the panel where all the numbers coincide with a certain floors. "B" is for basement and "G" is for the garage underneath the buildings. From what I can see, there are 41 floors including the lobby, but there are 42 in total, for the 42nd floor would be label "P" for penthouse.

Unusually, the elevator we're in stops on on the 40th floor. The door opens to a regular floor. Alan tries to hit the penthouse button again, but all it does is close the doors. The elevator doesn't go up any higher. "What do we do?" I ask.

"I don't know," he tells me and he lets go of my arm and tries to press the penthouse button again. He tries this for four more times, with the same outcome. "Maybe it's a glitch. I do remember this building to be very new compared to the other buildings. Maybe the penthouse button is broken. We can either switch elevators and see if the other ones go higher or we can just go up one floor and then use the stairs from then on. Then again, we can just go someplace else and I'll just let you choose."

What should we do?
135333331111131133.title: Not High Enough

choices: We are ambushed by a group of men in suits
We find it to be locked
We find it to be open; we are able to leave
1353333311111311331.content:
"I guess we can switch elevators and see if that'll work," I tell him of my choosing.

"Okay, let's do that," Alan agrees and he pushes the button to open the doors and they open into the floor again. He walks out and i follow after him. Once we are on the hallway, we turn around and watch the doors close before us. I watch the numbers count down as the very elevator that we were on goes back down to the lobby. Alan pushes the call button and we wait for an elevator to start rising to our current floor. A ding accompanies the opening of doors of the elevator to our right. I walk in first while Alan follows me in. "Alright, here goes." He presses the penthouse button, which for a moment lights up. It causes the doors to close. The next moment, the light illuminating the penthouse button dims and another lights up. The button that lights up is the "B" button for basement.

Without warning, the elevators starts to lower itself the most lowest floor. It means what it means. In the elevators, the "G" button for garage sits right above the button for the basement, meaning the basement is below the underground parking garage underneath the hotel. Alan tries hard to stop the elevator from making it way to the basement level. He tries to push every button for other floors, but they don't light up when he presses them. He also tries to apply the emergency brakes, but that fails as well. The only good thing about this is that the elevator is lowering itself at the very same pace as it had went up, meaning the elevator isn't falling. But that's the only good thing about this. We certainly won't get killed, but this moment I have a bad feeling like something or someone is waiting for us in the basement.

There's nothing we can do. Alan had told me that the elevator glass was bulletproof and soundproof, so there isn't any chance we can break it open or shout to people in the lobby about our predicament. In a last ditch effort, I try to pound on the glass as we pass the 20th floor. Unfortunately, no one is in the lobby right now. Actually, there are workers here, but they don't dare look up at the elevators, no matter how significant they are in this lobby.

Eventually, we get to the basement. The doors open and a semi-dark, semi-lit basement sits before us. Toiletries of different kinds sit wrapped in plastic and are stacked on wooden pallets, filed against the wall to our left. A pallet jack sits to our right, against the opposite wall.

Alan tries to again, push every button he could find inside the elevator, again to no avail. I suggest, "Can't we just find the stairs and just leave this place?"

"Good idea," Alan says, with a bit of embarrassment in his face. He exits the elevator and unwittingly takes my hand (thankfully he doesn't interlock his fingers) and leads me hurriedly down the basement corridor. We get to a crossroads of corridors. In this T-intersection, the left hallway is packed with pallets of unopened boxes. Though there is space to squeeze through, we decide to instead continue down the hallway where it's much more open.

I share Alan's nervousness, as his palms get sweaty and his breathing quickens. His pace doesn't speed up though, as if he clearly knows he's pulling along a woman in heels. The hallway turns right and we come to another intersection, this time branch out into three hallways. The hallways are well-lit, but unfortunately, there are too many object in them to navigate through. We continue down until we see a sign with a line that zigs and zags up and to the right. We both know that's the symbols for the stairs. Alan rushes along to the lit door, though not too fast as to make me trip on my dress. When we get to the door, does anything happen?
1353333311111311331.title: The Switch (The Basement)

choices: Start investigating the computer
Wait until the doctor comes back
Explore the rest of the home for places to investigate
1353333311113.content:
When I peek out my head out to see who or what is in the room with me, I discover nobody human. A dog, who looks to be a purebred German Shepherd, is laying in his comfy bed on the opposite side of the room. He immediately perks his head up with his pointy ears at attention when he sees me appear from behind the drapes. I had enjoyed dogs when I was a man, but knowing I may be a stranger to this dog, I don't move an inch from my position. When he gets on his feet and trots over, the bell on his collar jingling with ever step, I get a bit defensive. What damage can a full grown German Shepherd to a naked woman?

He prances over to a table off to the side and I watch him grab a piece of paper off the table with his mouth. When he turns his head and his eyes catch mine, I freeze, except for my hands, which manipulates the drapes to hide everything below my neck. He walks over to me and using the gap that I had left between one edge of the drapes and the post holding up the canopy of the bed, he jumps and infiltrates the interior. I stay still, hoping that no sudden moves would startle him into attacking me. I sense him on the bed behind me and my wild imagination assumes him as a rabid wolf with teeth bared ready to intercept his prey, though I don't hear any growling. He moves in to my side and lays himself beside me.

I look down at him and with innocent eyes, he looks back, raising his head to directly hand me the piece of paper. I reluctantly take it from him and unfold it. I let go of the drapes to hold the note with two hands. The paper reads:

"To whom it may concern,

If you are reading this, then I'm glad to see that you are well and awake. Please do not mind Rango. You are no stranger to him, so he's harmless.

I do not doubt you have a whole lot of questions and I will answer them to the best of my ability when I get back from the clinic. My home is available to you. Please recuperate yourself with whatever I have and if you need clothes, I've managed to provide you some. They are sitting on the table.

I'll see you when I get back.

-Dr. Murao"

I have my suspicions and they all start with how friendly this doctor is. How friendly is he to take in a wounded man only to transform him into a healthy person... with boobs!? And to take him... her back to his wonderful abode? I smell something fishy here and a bit of investigating should be done. Since I don't have a handy detective or gumshoe around, I'll have to do it myself.

I step out of bed, my feet feeling the cool hardwood floor that encompasses the whole spacious room. Rango, the German Shepherd jumps off the bed and follows close behind. I ask the dog, "Why is it that you follow me like this?" As if he is another human, I cover my exposed body with my arms and walk briskly to the table. A stack of clothes sits folded neatly on the table, like the letter said. I inspect each garment and come to find it's not much. A bra and matching thong and a satin bathrobe that when worn, only covers most of my torso and barely covers my ass. If anything, these clothes will cover me somewhat. New questions does present itself. How did this doctor acquire these for me? Is there or was there someone living here that wasn't a man? Or... maybe this doctor is not a man at all?

Anyways, I manage to put on the garments with no hassle and they do a good job keeping me a bit warm. I can't say it does much for my legs, but it'll do. The thong in fact is snug against my crotch and even though it leaves my butt cheeks exposed, it's not that bad. The bra as well supports my breasts and keeps them from swaying left and right when I walk. The satin robe, along with covering my torso, feels like it isn't there.

Now that I'm clothed, though not in a manner that is in my favor, now would be a good time to investigate. A clock mounted on the wall tells me it's close to noon, so give or take an hour, I should have five hours to check up on this doctor. Where should I start? I see a computer near Rango's bed, but the open door to the rest of the home invites me to other places within it. Then again, I could just wait for the doctor to come back to answer any questions I may have.

What should I do?
1353333311113.title: German Shepherd

choices: A wanted poster for my wounded self
A news article with a portrait of my female face
A picture of an older gentleman posing with this woman I'm personifying
13533333111131.content:
The computer, whether it may be locked or not, should be a good place to start looking. If it's not in the computer, there should be a places in the desk where vital information is kept. I walk over to the desktop, noting that the way I walk is much different. It's more practical than intentional. Without a dick to get in the way, i can walk as if I'm on a tightrope. I wonder if this is how I would walk with heels on. Not that I'm curious though. Just concerned, that's all.

Rango follows me closely, more like a sidekick that a guard dog or service animal. Since he doesn't get in my way, I ignore him and let him be.
Halfway between the table and the desk, I spot my reflection in a full-sized mirror standing near what looks like a dresser. If I was a man, I would be attracted to this new me, which further makes me cringe knowing my male mind is attracted to this female body I'm inhabiting.

Once at the desk, I pull out the office chair and take a seat. I have to adjust it so my eyes are level with the middle of the screen. On the tower, the green light that would illuminate the symbol shaped like a open circle with a short line jutting through its top flashes, telling me that the computer is either asleep or hibernating. I find the mouse and click the left button, which activates the fan in the computer tower and therefore, wakes up the computer. The screen turns on and an account shows up. I assume, since it's been idling for enough time to have it go to sleep, the computer would ask for a password. To my surprise, it doesn't and automatically opens up and shows the activity that was on the screen before it went to sleep.

I'm shocked to see on the screen... what?
13533333111131.title: Desktop

choices: A man in a leather jacket
A delivery man with a large package
An older gentleman wearing a white lab coat
135333331111311.content:
I can't believe it, but the circumstances last night checks out. When the screen opens to the actual activity that was on the screen before the computer went to sleep, I'm shocked to find a wanted poster to my male persona. Even the name matches. The poster reads, "Wanted for Murder, Resisting Arrest and Grand Theft Auto. Cesar Lopez. Last seen: Downtown, near Shopping District." A number is listed below a criminal mugshot of my face, which looks different since I've never grown a beard that long before. Below the listed number, a reward is also written to a hefty twenty-five grand. What did I do to garner accusation of murder, resisting arrest and grand theft auto? And what did I experience last night to garner me a bloody mess in my abdomen? Here's another question: when this doctor put me in this body, where did he leave the dying remains?

This information leaves me confused. Should I be sad that my male self is dead, rotting like a corpse in some dump? Or should I feel grateful for this doctor for doing whatever he or she did? Or should I be mad that he or she couldn't put me in a better body, one that matched the previous?

Before I can choose what to feel at this moment, the doorbell to the home rings. Rango, just like a dog would when a stranger approaches, barks. He does this loudly, enough to get me off my feet and over to him to shut him up. A good pad and rub on his head calms him down, but it's not enough when the door rings again, causing Rango to go off like an unattended grenade with its pin removed. He leaves me no choice but to search for the front door and answer it.

To the left of the bed, there is a door, ajar, leading outside into a hallway, I open it wide to indeed find a hallway beyond its threshold. To my immediate right, there is a door which turns out to be a closet filled with coats and shoes. Rango instead walks the other way, down to the left. I follow him and get to a clearing, which turns out to be an high-ceiling skylight. The sun, which sits high above the house, bears its rays straight through the tinted skylight and onto the spiral staircase below it. Without letting me know, Rango, still barking at each ringing of the door bell, makes his way does the stairs. I follow him to the bottom and into a foyer, where I find him pawing at a door. "This must be the front door," I say aloud and hear my voice for the first time. It's neither manly or deep in tone, but feminine and higher-pitched. One could say that my new voice sounds cute even.

I pull on Rango's collar to get him down onto all his four paws and to put him behind me. This way, he doesn't get any sly ideas of pouncing on the person on the other side of this door. The door bell rings again, causing Rango to go crazy and bark at the door. Since I'm already pissed at his barking, I bark back at him, "Shut up, Rango!" It's enough to get him to sit and shut his mouth for five minutes.

I unlock the door and twist the handle. I pull the door open and find... who?
135333331111311.title: Wanted

choices: working on it
1353333311113111.content:
I peek from behind the door to find a man whose back is turned to the door. He's tall, clearly a foot taller than my petite frame, and wears a leather jacket and jeans as his outfit. Judging from the emptiness of the driveway, this guy isn't any biker. He's too tall for one. "Excuse me," I timidly say.

The man turns around and is shocked when he sees me. "Gwen?" he asks, addressing me as this 'Gwen.'

"Who?" I ask.

He tries to respond, but gives an expression as if he has an epiphany or that he has realized something that he was told. "Sorry, uhm, I'm here for Dr. Murao, is he home?" he asks me after pausing for a bit.

"He isn't here," I tell him. "Who are you?"

He pulls out something from the inside of his leather jacket. It turns out to be a leather wallet. He flips it open and shows me a badge with an identification card along with it, while introducing himself, "I'm Detective Dyson Bell. My partner is with Dr. Murao at his clinic. I'm here to check up on his alibis."

"Then why did you ask me if Dr. Murao was here?" I ask, pointing out the obvious.

"I was just making sure he wasn't in two places at once," the detective tells me. "May I come inside?"

"Don't you need a warrant for that?" I ask him. "And what alibis? Is the doctor in trouble?"

"No trouble, really, but I'd be more comfortable if I was out of this heat," the detective says while pushing against the door, widening it. I get out of the way, hoping Rango would be a good dog and attack this man. Instead, and to my surprise, he acts more friendly than aggressive towards the man. "Hey Rango," he says as he pats the dog.

I'm shocked at how friendly the dog is to the stranger. Is he even a stranger to him? It's like the dog is familiar and happily accepting of the man. He even sits calmly at his side. I close the door and lock and then turn my attention back to the man. "You've been here before?"

"Dr. Murao used to be my neighbor. As his friend, he asked of a favor. Since he's sort of on "clinic" arrest, I'm tasked with checking his house on any leads," he explains.

"Leads?" I ask. "What has he done?"

"Nothing, really, but my partner is old-school and won't settle down without turning over every rock in this case. A criminal was found dead in an alley near the back door of his clinic. Turns out he came to the door and knocked on it. He was wounded in his abdomen, like he was stabbed several times. The blood that was on his hands belonged to him. The blood found on the door, also belonged to him," he tells me. I sort of get an uneasy knot in my stomach. "Dr. Murao has been very honest with us. He said he took the man in, not knowing he was a criminal, and generously tended to him. The man turned out to be very resistant and didn't want anesthesia at all. The doctor couldn't even help him with his limited tools."

"Are you saying Dr. Murao killed that man?" I ask.

"If you mean kill as in not help him, then yes, but since the doctor wanted to help and the man refused, then whoever stabbed him, killed him," he explains.

"So if it looks like Dr. Murao didn't kill him, why are you here then?" I ask him.

"You with all your questions, girl," he exclaims, calling me the female that I am. "Dr. Murao asked me to personally come and watch the house. Considering the way the man was stabbed with the proximity of the doctor's clinic near the crime scene, we believe that the assailant will want to tie up loose ends."
1353333311113111.title: Detective Dyson

choices: Dr. Murao comes home at the right moment
I try to search more on the computer
An answer presents itself with an uninvited visitor
135333331111312.content:
I'm shocked to see a portrait of my female face on the screen. There is a year on the photo, in small numbers written in the corner, reading, "2012." The portrait is attached to a document of sorts and when I scroll down, seeing a headline and a body to it, I figure it's a news article that is yet to be submitted and published in print. But why is my face on the article.

I begin reading it, starting with the headline, "GIRL, IN COMA SINCE 2012, WAKES UP. Gwen Murao, only daughter of Dr. Vincent Murao, was the victim of a horrible car accident while coming home from a party in summer of 2012. Gwen was driving her white Toyota Corolla, using a back road to avoid an accident on the highways, where instead of four lanes to navigate, she could only use one.

The cause for the accident would be Cesar Lopez, who was intoxicated twice the legal limit. While Gwen was driving down a slope on the back road, Cesar was driving up the slope, swerving in and out of his lane. He would eventually swerve at the last second over the double yellow line on head on with Gwen's vehicle. The two cars collided at 12:30am on that Saturday night.

The accident was found by Detective Dyson Bell, who was off-duty at the time. Upon inspecting, he found Cesar was nowhere to be found, He called the paramedics after finding the state Gwen was found in. Gwen suffered several lacerations as she was partially ejected through the windshield, which shattered upon impact. Thankfully, she was wearing her seat belt. Her other injuries included a neck injury and a few broken ribs. Her friends, who designated Gwen as their driver and who had been drinking heavily that night, only sustained minor injuries.

Gwen had been taken to Trinity General Hospital where she was treated for her injuries. Unfortunately, due to the trauma, she stayed in a coma-like state. Upon request, Dr. Murao had request she be moved to her home in the hills.

On September 28, 2015..." When I get to this part, I stop to find out what the exact date it is today. After finding a calendar in the computer, I find that this date is just two days from today, which is September 26. I continue reading the rest of the article. "...Upon visiting the Murao residence, the person who had found the accident three years ago, Detective Dyson Bell, was surprised to find Gwen waking up from her comatose slumber." The rest of the article is blank which makes this one of the shortest articles I've ever read.

But this woman I'm personifying, her body, her look, is this Dr. Murao's daughter? And she's been in a coma for three years? And this Cesar Lopez. This is me. This Cesar is me. He has a small picture attached to the side of the article and it's my face with a bunch of facial hair on it. I was hoping this article would answer my questions, but all it does is give me more questions to ask. The most pressing question: Why did this doctor put me in this body when I, Cesar Lopez, was the one to put his daughter in a coma?

How do I go about answering that major question?
135333331111312.title: Before the Press

choices: working on this
1353333311113123.content:
Rango makes a sound behind me and when I look at him, he gives me a confused look. Did he hear something? If he's acting like this, then this Dr. Murao shouldn't be home. I get up out of the chair and go to the entrance of the room. The door is ajar and open enough for me to stick my head out. I hear nothing for a moment, but in the next moments, I hear something like a door unlocking. A beeping that sounds like it's from an alarm system is heard as a door is opened.

I sneak out into the hallway and find a open room that has a banister surrounding a spiral staircase in the center of it. A skylight sits right above, flooding the room with natural light. I spy from the banister towards the foyer a guy with a leather jacket on. He doesn't look like Dr. Murao, since he's younger-looking and doesn't have the clothes of a doctor. He surely doesn't look like the father of Gwen... me. If it's not Dr. Murao, then he must be a squatter who managed to open the front door. I see Rango follow close behind and I gesture to him to stay where he is at the top of the steps.

Since I can't call the police on the guy, knowing that mostly everyone knows that I'm in a coma (the article I read was not published yet), I'll have to deal with him myself. I sneak down the stairs and follow down the path where I saw the man go. I also note which parts of the house are where. As he would have taken a right from the foyer, the man had passed an office with a computer to his right, which is a sign that he isn't a thief, since he could have easily taken those items in the office and pawned them for money. Across the way from the office is a full-sized kitchen, which a squatter would take advantage due to the food stored here. Down the walkway between the office and kitchen is a hallway that goes to several rooms. The first of which, located on the left, is a laundry room. The next door, on the right is where the guy went. I know because it's the loudest out of all the rooms. The television is on and it seems he just went to the bathroom since the toilet flushed.

I enter, seeing no sign of the man in the room. He placed his bags on the bed and his jacket on the chair and I also see something else on the table. A gun. I pick it up with the intent on scaring him out. I wait in the room until he is done washing his hands in the sink.

He walks out and for a second there, I startled by how tall he is. Comparing him to my height, he is clearly at least half a foot taller than me. He also has his shirt off, showing toned arms, chest and abdomen. In my fright, I lift the gun to aim it at him. "Who are you and what are you doing here!" I yell.

He puts his hands up and says, "You startled me." He looks me up and down and also eyes the gun for a few seconds.

"I'm not afraid to use this!" I shout at him, closing the distance as if I want to make sure I hit him with a bullet when in truth, I don't want to shoot him, just scare him.

He then visibly calms down. "I would have shot the gun by now, but I know you can't even do that much."

"Don't make me do it--!" I shout, but with quick succession, he grabs the gun and even grabs my arms and pulls me toward him. I'm too slow to react and he single-handedly takes the gun out of my hands while turning me around while pinning my arms behind me.

He chuckles as he points out the things I've done wrong. "If you're going to scare a man, make sure you take the gun off of safety and make sure it's loaded and cocked too," he says while brandishing the flawed weapon in front of my face. "Also, don't close the distance between yourself and an attacker, because he can easily grab you and put in a situation like this. Much more easier with a gun that's not loaded."

"Alright, you win, but you won't get away with this. I'll call the police when I get the chance," I threaten him.

"No need," he says and puts what sounds like cuffs on my hands. I try to struggle but it's too late. He shoves me onto the bed and goes to his jacket. He pulls out a wallet and opens it, showing me a badge and an identification card. "Because I AM the police." He puts the gun and his badge onto the table and turns to me. "Since you aimed a firearm at an officer of the law, then it's not me that's in trouble, but you. So do you have anything to say for yourself, in your defense?"

I sit up and move so that I'm seated at the edge of the bed. "Don't I have a right not to say anything?"

The man chuckles. "Dr. Murao said you had fire, but he didn't say you were smart too."

I'm surprised. This man isn't Dr. Murao. He knows him though. Some of my questions are starting to be answered. I look around the room and see the pictures of him and Dr. Murao. There's even a photo of him and Rango, who silently infiltrates the room and takes a seat on the bed right beside me.

"How are you, Gwen?" he asks me, and by name too.
1353333311113123.title: Residing Squatter (Untimely Rouse)

choices: The man surprises me by uncovering the curtain I'm hiding behind
He calls out to me saying he can see me
I try to sneak for the door, but I find that I cannot open it
135333331112.content:
I suddenly come to, not as a someone waking up from a long slumber, but as one who simply appears out of thin air, though experienced in the first-person rather than second. One second, my life is fading on the floor of the a clinic I stumbled into, the next I'm suddenly on my feet. I do not feel the wound and its stinging, throbbing pain. Rather, I feel nothing along the lines of pain and discomfort. All I feel is cold tiles underneath my feet.

I try to look down at my feet to wonder why I'm have no shoes or at least some socks on, but before I see the floor, I see a surreal scene before me. It's like a dream that is soon to be a nightmare. Before me, lying on a table, is my body, wounded and from what I can tell, lifeless. The body's face belongs to me, though I may have let my facial hair grow out longer than usual. The clothes and the blood staining the parts around the wound still look wet and fresh. I lean in to investigate further, but a sound from the corridor stops me from doing so. I frantically search around the room for a place to hide, but I cannot find any place big enough for me. I see a door that is opposite the corridor, so I try to go and open it. I twist the doorknob and hear footsteps on the tiles behind me. Resistance prevents me from twisting the doorknob all the way, signaling to me that the door is locked. Soon, the footsteps get louder. I have no time. It's too late.

I turn around and a man with a lab coat reveals himself from behind a curtain, which also reveals that this place is not a clinic at all but more along the lines of a morgue. Steel doors small enough to only allow a drawer with a body through line the walls of the back of the room. My lifeless body on the table looks right at home here. The man walks over to the table and faces it, but for a moment glances towards me. He stares as he intends to look right through me, at the door behind me. For some reason, I just stand there, frozen in place. Even though I blanketed in the shadows, a part of me thinks that he still sees me. Miraculously, instead of calling me out, he turns back to the table like he didn't notice me at all. I take this chance and go over to the side to hide behind another curtain, opposite the one the man came from.

He speaks out loud, probably into a tape recorder, certain things about the body laying on the table. His voice is hoarse, as if he is sick with a sore throat. "This is Dr. Monroe, examined a possible John Doe. Looks to be either an Asian or Hispanic male in his mid-20s. I neglected to lock the back door and he happened to stumble in. He was soaked both in water and blood. Tried to resuscitate him, but he could not wake from his unconsciousness. It seems he was too weak and succumbed to his wounds," he says into the recorder.

"He does have a wallet, but all that is found is a couple of large bills. It looks he suffered from a gunshot to the abdomen, which from appearance of the exit wound, looks like he was fleeing as he was shot from behind. It seems that he was chased into the alleyways prior to him showing up at my backdoor. Well, who am I kidding?"

What happens next?
135333331112.title: Out of Body Experience

choices: You cansee me?
1353333311122.content: "I know you're hiding behind the curtain!" the man says right after turning off his recorder. "
1353333311122.title: Not My Body

choices: An unaware woman with a gun in her hand
A woman in a police uniform
A prostitute
1353333312.content:
As I stand in the puddle and flick my hands downward to remove excess water, I hear something above the busyness of the street. I can barely make out the sounds of more than one pair of footsteps approaching, but what dominates that is the sound of men. A shout, which sounds authoritative like that of a leader, is heard over all those sounds. The voice shouts, "Check the alleys! He couldn't have gone far!" There is no reason for me to be in this alley in the first place. Actually, I tend to avoid alleyways because they serve as hiding spots from the exposure and somewhat clearer visibility of the streets. I have no intention of hiding, but why am I here in this alley? Am I running from someone? Are these men looking for me? And for what reason?

The adrenaline in my body causes me to continue forward, although slowly, deeper into the alleyway. I look behind me and spot a man suddenly appearing from the wall at the end of the alley. When he shouts, "I found him! He's over here!" my slow trod down the alley rapidly becomes a jog, which eventually turns into a desperate sprint. I run down the alley, coming to an intersection. I find that there is more than one person pursuing me and when I try to hang a right into a different alley, I find two men appear from the street. I double back to the intersection and try the alleyway that would have been directly across from my previous alley, the one with the puddle. I stop in my tracks when another man appears. With only one option left, I hand a left down the only other alleyway. To hinder my pursuers, I knock down whatever I can find, whether it be trash cans, empty wooden pallets or unused, rotting planks of wood.

I carefully navigate the alleyway while trying to distance myself from the men chasing me. I get to what seems to be a T-intersection, with an alleyway continuing forward and another branching to my right. After seeing the evidence of what looks like a street at the end of the alleyway right across from me, I turn to the right, only to run into.... who?
1353333312.title: Pursued

choices: In a bed in a lavish hotel room
On a moldy mattress in an abandoned factory
Restrained to a cold-steel table in what looks to be a morgue
13533333121.content:
I only saw a glimpse of her before running into her. If I could pause that moment before the collision, I can see that she was indeed shorter than me, maybe about half a foot or a foot shorter. Despite her size compared to mine, the look on her face was that of a determined expression. It was as if she knew me and why the men were chasing me. In her hands was a gun, which immediately caused my instincts to fire. As I collided into her, it was in the form of a tackle. Using my weight, I managed to topple her backward, but with some amazing footwork, she was able to get me flat on my back and sending me into another puddle, though considerably smaller than the first. Nevertheless, both the front and back of my body were soaked with water.

She still held the gun in her hand and before she could lift it to aim at my head, I wrestled it out of her hand. To my amazement, I am somehow able to get a hold of the gun while forcibly dismounting the woman from my body. Before she can recover, I'm already on my feet and dishonorably kicking the woman into some trash cans. That's when I see the men appear in the intersection of the alley. I find an opportunity to make a last stand, and with the gun in my hand, I grab onto the woman's collar and pull her upward. I force her to sit upright and I aim the muzzle of the gun to the back of her head. Surprisingly, I'm able to shout at my pursuers, saying, "Don't move another inch! Or else I'll blow her brains out all over this alley."

"You don't want to do that!" one of men says. His hand shakes as he holds his gun up and directed towards me. My mind registers it as an eagerness to kill me by pulling the trigger. Without warning, I open fire on the man, causing the men before me to duck for cover. I shoot off more rounds, sending the deafening sounds to echo up and down the alleyway. I kick the woman aside, telling myself she'll only slow me down. I start up down the alleyway and before I can get to the end of it, a stinging pain is felt in my leg. It sends me to the floor as I trip on it. When i look back, the woman has crawled over to her comrades and taken one of their guns and is aiming it at me. To prevent a killing shot, I shoot back, successfully impacting the arm holding the gun up. I stagger to the corner where I continue to flee.

When I get to a door that leads to stairs, I slump against the wall adjacent to it. I suddenly feel a different pain that prevents me from moving. i discover that it's not the leg that has been shot and is bleeding, but it's my head. It feel like my brain is being ripped apart, but by what? Before I know it, I black out from the headache. When I come to, where do I find myself?
13533333121.title: Collision

choices: The bathroom
In a living area, with men seated on the couches
In a living area, with no people present
135333331211.content:
I wake up very suddenly, shooting up into a sitting position, as if my previous altercation with the men and one woman in that alley had just been a nightmare. With brunette strands falling in front of my face, I quickly realize that the previous incident had been the dream and this reality that I'm in right now is the nightmare. I immediately freeze as the strands of hair fall in front of my face. Slowly, I bring my hand up and gently grab several locks and slide it to one side where I finish by tucking them behind my right ear. I do the same with my other hand on the other side of my head, tucking the lock I grab over my left ear.

With the hair out of the way, I can clearly see the scene before me. I'm no longer in the alley and it's no longer nighttime. It's cool in the room, a bit warm underneath the blanket I find myself under, but it contrasts the bitter cold of that alley. Plus, I'm not soaked to the bone in stagnant water. My eyes wander downward and indeed, my clothes as dry as they can be, but it's not the clothes I'm worried about. It's the body that is wearing those clothes. Two mounds, not too small, but not too big, protrude from my chest. I raise my right hand to cup one of them and my hand can fully encompasses the globe with my fingers touching all sides of the base of the flesh. I immediately let go of the breast when I notice gauze.

Wrapped with a bandage, the gauze is placed over an area of my upper arm, which, upon touching the center, causes the wound that's covered to sting. I gasp in pain with a higher-pitched voice. The pain although has a benefit and it helps me remember the interactions I had last. I try to recall last night and try to remember my perspective of me wielding a gun toward four people at the end of that alley. I somehow cannot and my mind only recollects a perspective that is low to the ground. I actually notice that I'm on my side with a gun in my hand, which struggles to aim at a man that I had just shot. This man is limping on a leg that has a bullet from the gun I'm holding. I see the man shoot his gun and not even a second later, my arm explodes with the bullet's impact.

I'm knocked out of my reverie by the trauma and I find myself hyperventilating. I slide out of bed, noticing the slender legs of this body as well as the black panty and the white tanktop it's wearing. I make my way to a door which I believe is the bathroom and before going inside, I calm myself down. Once my breathing is under control, I feel around the inside wall of the room and flip a switch. I push on the door, finding myself.... where?
135333331211.title: Second-Person Perspective

choices: Get out of bed and into some clothes and sneak out
Stay and confront the issue
Stay in bed
1353333312112.content:
I calmly push on the door, believing to enter the bathroom, when in actuality, I walk into a living space. Immediately to my right there is a small, partially-closed kitchen and beyond that is the living area, which is a dining room in the far right corner with a pair of couches and a television tucked in the left corner. There are people present, men in matching suits with no ties. Upon my entry, all of the men turn their heads. It's when the last one turns his head, something in my mind recalls and recognizes his face and out of nowhere, I bolt for the door. I manage to open it rather quickly and without thinking, in just a tanktop and a pair of panties, I run out into the hallway. There is no logical reason why I'm running away, as if there was a trigger that caused me to run as if I was being pursued. Pursued like last night.

I deduce where the elevator would be and run down the hallway towards it. I look behind me for a split second and see the very man I recognize come out of the door. This startles me for a brief moment and I accelerate to get to the elevator faster. Within five yards from the elevator, the chime chirps out letting me know that the lift has opened on this floor, but when I'm about to turn into the open lift, three men exit out of it: an older gentlemen flanked by two younger and taller men.

At the sight of them, I reel back and eventually fall to the ground, landing on my bad arm. As I turn to go the other way, in my haste, I ignore the stinging pain shooting all through my right side, but it proves to be my downfall. In my panic, my body is way too far in shock and my legs give out, sending my half-naked body to the floor. I roll over to my side and slowly slip into unconsciousness. The last things I see is the older gentlemen's face hovering over my, but at a distance. The man who I recognized from the alley dominates my view as his face is more closer, considering him to be on his knees trying to wake me up. I black out shortly after.

I wake up again in the very same bed I find myself in. This time, I don't wake up suddenly, but very subtly I open my eyes. I'm immediately aware of my surroundings, most especially of what I can hear. I hear a conversation and judging by how it's handled in whispers, the two men who are speaking are trying to keep their discussion from the wrong ears. Somehow, with the ears of this woman, I can hear them clearly.

“She wasn't supposed to be out there in the first place. If it weren't for her though, Cesar Lopez would be...” For a moment I drown out their voice at the mention of my name. Cesar Lopez was my first and last name the last time I had it before I was slapped by Tyrone. Wait. I still remember that? How is it that I remember three different sets of memories? So, I was Cesar before the slap and I was Cesar after finding myself in that alley. But what's the reason why I was on the run from those men? And how did I end up in this woman's body. I drown out my thoughts to continue listening. “So, what do we do with Eliza? You've seen her. Her encounters with Cesar have distracted her. Ever since he joined our task force, she has been slacking. What should we do with her?”

The question stirs something inside of me. What is this feeling? It's as if I'm a dog who is on her last legs and the only option is to put her down. What should I do? Should I quickly get out of bed and into some decent clothing and sneak my way out of this ominous situation? Or should I stay and actually confront the men about what they are discussing about me? Or should I not worry about it and stay in bed?
1353333312112.title: Eliza

choices: Go to a pawnshop to sell the guns and phone
Go to a park to dump the guns and phone in a trash bin
Go to a restaurant to eat and examine my wallet
13533333121121.content:
I take the question quite seriously and I feel like they view me as an asset that is not that beneficial to them anymore. My mind wanders into situations that involve them ridding me discreetly. Not liking where the conversation is going, I slip out of bed, finding myself in the same clothes as before: a black tanktop and a bra pair of panties. I tip-toe to the closet and find nothing but an unopened suitcase. I open it and find several pieces of clothing that I have to take out and unfold just to make sure what they are. Generally, they look like they can fit on this smaller body and since I'm the only woman in this suite, I deduce this is the only bag with garments made for a female.

I take a simple outfit: a khaki, mid-sleeve outerwear button-up that's more rough and durable than a dress shirt, a black V-neck T-shirt, and a black pair of capris that cut off a couple inches below the knee. Not worrying about how it looks and concerning myself only with my current nakedness, I quickly dress myself up. I finish with a black pair of ankle socks and slip on some peculiar shoes, which turn out to be the only pair of shoes that are in my size. The shoes are like canvas sneakers, colored entirely in black, though the canvas does not stop at the ankle. It actually rises from the heel and stops just under my knees. These can be considered more to be boots than sneakers. Or a tall shoe, perhaps, since the soles are like those of everyday canvas sneakers. I take my time with the shoes, since I do have to tighten up each crossing of the two laces so that they cinch up every part of the canvas to my calves. Before leaving the room, I look to see if there is any wallet that belongs to me. In my search, i discover a leather wallet sitting on the nightstand next to the bed. I take it with me, sliding in into my outerwear shirt pocket

Once I'm done, I make my way to the very same door that lead out to the main living area. I pull the door, which is slightly ajar, revealing two men in suits standing not too far from the door frame. One leans on the kitchen counter while the other stands straight. When they see me come out of the room, they stand at attention. Judging from their expressions, they look surprised. "Eliza! You're awake!" the shorter man, they one who was leaning on the counter exclaims.

"Shouldn't you be in bed? You're still recovering from that gunshot wound," the taller man warns me.

"I'm feel fine," I say, trying to hide the fact that I'm trying to sneak out. "I just wanted to get some air."

Two smaller of the two looks towards the group of men seated on the couch. Fortunately, the man who somehow triggered my sudden half-naked run into the hallway isn't here, but the older gentlemen is present, and he is the one who gives a positive-looking signal to the man who silently asks for approval. The smaller man turns and tells me, "If you're going to go out, you'll need your phone and guns on you, just in case. Did you get your holsters?" I shake my head, which causes the taller man to shake his head before entering the room.

He comes back with a standard pair of holsters that already have loaded pistols in each holster. "Remember to wear these underneath your shirt. You don't want to cause a panic in the city at this time of day," the taller man explains to me. "Report your location every hour."

"Got it," I say and round the two men and make my way to the door. I open it, this time calm and relaxed. I have no one pursuing me and I have no reason to think that way. I exit out the suite and close the door behind me. I make my way down the hallway to the elevator. I look behind me, just in case, but after staring down the hallway for a good ten seconds, all I find is an empty hallway devoid of any men trying to run after me. I turn back to the elevator and press the call button.

I arrive in the lobby shortly after and I make my way out to the street. The streets have all types of vehicles passing by and pedestrians mind their own business as they walk back and forth on the sidewalks and crosswalks. Where should I go and what should I do there?
13533333121121.title: Sneak Out

choices: Laying on the backseat of a limo, my head sitting in someone's lap
Seated uncomfortably in a chair in an interrogation room
Laying on a gurney with a flashlight shining in my eyes
13533333123.content:
It's bound to happen and in this instance it did. These alleyways are not just empty side streets that the locals avoid. They are home to a collection of different people of various professions, some, if not all, of them leaning towards the illegal side. And when I turn that corner, I run straight into a woman. At first glance, she looks out of place. Her brown hair is done, she has a dress that tells me that she was out partying in these twilight hours, and she has heels that scream out a borderline "porn star." But it's the heavy makeup on her face and the evidence that she was hit across the cheek tells me otherwise. She's a prostitute and I've run her over in my haste to get away from these men. I try to avoid her using a cross between a football player's spin move and a ballroom dance move. I use her as a turnstile and I might have grabbed her arm as well, which is adorned with a heavy silver bangle. I make it to the other side, but at the cost of her falling to the ground hard. The gentleman in me wants to help her up, but it's when the men chasing me show up from around the T-intersection in the alley that makes me think otherwise. I run down the alley way, successfully maneuvering my way around successive trash cans and refuse.

I run for what seems like hours, never looking back at my pursuers. I don't have a destination and it seems like I have no place to go that would save me from the men chasing me. Why are they chasing me in the first place? And why do I feel sleepy? I black out without feeling myself fall to the ground.

Will these black outs and states of unconsciousness ever end? Where do I end up after this?
13533333123.title: Angel of the Night

choices: Not done yet
135333331232.content:
I wake up upright in an room devoid of any decorations. The only fixture on the blank walls is a large mirror and immediately I see something has changed. The reflection I see in the mirror is that of the same woman that I used as a turnstile in that alley. Her face, her outfit, her whole image in the mirror is as vivid as she was in that alley. "Oh fuck," I say and the woman's mouth moves the same way as if she is copying me. But when my eyes move down, the things I see validate that the reflection is real. The first thing I see are two mound of flesh protruding from my chest, which is no longer broad but slender. The breasts are medium-sized, about the size that is close to my preference. They fill up the dress that I'm wearing, but from my perspective, the dress is tight enough that it create a cleavage that I can look down upon, as if it's a bottomless pit.

Despite of the look of this new body I find myself in, I feel some manipulations to it. The dominant feeling I sense is that my hands are connected to each other and my arms right behind this very uncomfortable chair. It's so uncomfortable that I'm squirming in my seat. What also makes it uneasy to sit in it is that my feet, which are inserted in high heels, are also bound to the legs of the chair. Any type of attempt to escape the chair either causes pain or more discomfort. How did I get I in this body? And why am I handcuffed to this chair?

Suddenly, I hear a door unlocking and the doorknob twisting. The creak of hinges signals the opening of a door, but from what I can see, it's not in my field of vision. Judging from the sound, I can sense that the door is right behind me. The hinges creak more and in the shadow I see behind me in the reflection, there is a door and it opens widely to reveal a tall person. This person walks in and exposes himself in the dim lighting. He's Caucasian as far as I can see. He wears a black and white suit with a solid black tie. He has a stoic expression on his face that is almost intimidating. His eyes are already directing at my own as he rounds my position and takes a half-seat on the table. In his hands is a dark brown folder which looks to be filled with all sorts of forms and documents. He slams it on the table and sternly looks at me. I flinch when the folder hits the top of the table.

"Do you like prolonging this?" the man asks me. He doesn't let me answer. "First with this Cesar Lopez and now with this girl you're now in." The man says the name that is my actual name. Whoever I was before this, I was this Cesar that he is talking about. "Didn't we tell you that this power you have is too volatile to let loose? You've displaced two people from their own bodies and as a result, those two have already died due to our misunderstanding that it wasn't you in that body. But, it was your mistake for choosing to displace a prostitute. It didn't take long to find you." The man takes himself off the table and rounds the chair once more. Through the mirror, I see him bend over and whisper into my ear. "Good luck trying to get away from this mess you find yourself in."

He stands up and then goes to the door. He opens it and into the room walks in a man whom I do not recognize. He is a white man who is shirtless, exposing thick muscles on his arms and a muscular and toned chest. On his upper body he also has tattoos of various kinds adorning his skin.

"Meet Lucas. We've bailed him out for one purpose and that is to punish you. Unless you want to commit to us your services for the two deaths you allowed.
135333331232.title: Interrogation Room

choices: Something about the government passing a new law
The two of us have been selected to work our remaining sentences elsewhere
We have been chosen to fight eat other in the yard
135333332.content:
It's the sound of what sounds like a heavy metal door closing on its solid metal frame that wakes me up. I suddenly feel a soreness in my right cheek, but second later, I start to feel it spread throughout my body. I have to gasp in order to relieve myself of some of my stress. Funny it seems, that my voice is still mellow like a man, which causes me to double-check. From what I can feel, the manhood in my pants and the absence of fleshy globes on my chest tells me that I didn't change. “I didn't change?” I ask out loud.

“Can a man who's about to be released get any sleep?” the voice of a Hispanic man asks. Judging from where it's coming from, I deduce that it's right above me. I open my eyes and find myself is an almost dark room. To my immediate left is a wall of solid concrete, painted with off-white paint to smooth out the cracks and holes. Below me is a mattress, but remembering the bed I had before I was slapped, I figure this one is on the old side. It doesn't even feel like a proper cushion. It's as if all the soft stuff has been taken out and it's just its slightly-rough outer shell. It doesn't even prevent me from feeling the simple wires of the bed frame. Above me, or in other words, right in front of me as I lay down on this horrible mattress, is the underside of a bed frame. Bunk bed? I ask myself. To my right, I see the sight of three more walls, one of which has a metal grate as a door. The bars could only mean one this. This is no room. It's a cage. The glove had not changed me. It sent me into a cell. A prison cell.

Of all places, why a prison? I frantically ask in my mind. I immediately get out of bed and stand up, the bare soles of my feet feeling the cold on the rougher concrete floor. I back up against the wall opposite the two beds and see a person shuffling in the top bunk. His orange pants is the same color as my jumpsuit, reinforcing the fact that this is a real prison. I go over to the gate and look around. All I can see is more metal bar gates and more concrete walls. “Somebody! Get me out of here!” I shout out into the hallway. With no other object absorbing the sound of my shouting, the hard wall echo it into every cell, causing an uproar with the other inmates. Immediate after shouting, I can hear distant shouts telling me to shut up.

Then I'm suddenly grabbed by the shoulders and pulled off the metal bars. My grip falters and I'm sent to the floor hard. A silhouette of a muscular Hispanic man stands, blocking out the light coming from the hallway. “White boys don't know when to shut up. Can't you shut up so I can get a few more hours of sleep?” the man says.

“Hey, what's going on in there?” a deep voice comes from outside the cell. The Hispanic man moves out of the light to look behind him and there at the opening of our cell is a guard.

“Nothing here, sir. Puto can't wait to get out of here,” the Hispanic man responds.

“Well, turns out you two are being released early, regards from the warden,” the guard says. “Cuffs go back on. Prison policy still stands.” The guard presents a set of cuffs with a chain connecting both of them.

“Fine by me,” the Hispanic man says and then directs his words to me. “Happy now, puto?”

“You first, Garcia,” the guard says. My cell mate goes to the door faces his back to the bars. “Hands, Garcia.” He bends forward to insert his wrists into a larger rectangle in the middle of the door. At once, the guard places the cuffs on the Hispanic man's wrists and secures them. He pulls taut the chain connecting them together and stands back from the door. A buzzer sounds, causing the door to slide open automatically. The chain is let go, but two guards decked-out in riot gear enter the cell and push Garcia into the wall, pinning him there as they proceed to secure cuffs on his ankles. Both sets of cuffs are then connected to each other. The two guards escort the Hispanic man out of the cell and two more guards dressed in similar clothing take their place.

They roll me over and I don't resist them. If they are really releasing me, then I don't find any reason to rebel against my captors. There is only two questions in my mind: Why am I being released? And why is my cell mate being released along with me?
135333332.title: Bottom Bunk

choices: A large hanger at what sounds like an airport
A underground parking garage
The hold of a large cargo plane
1353333321.content:
After my cuffs are secured and I'm lifted to my feet (they don't bother giving me my socks or my shoes to put on either) and escorted out of the cell. As we pass the guard who isn't dressed in riot gear, I ask him a question. “Why am I being released?” I ask.

He stops the men from moving, so they just hold me in place. The guard then tells me, “It's the government, kid. They passed some law a few days ago. Turns out the prison system cannot afford to put a roof above your heads and feed you three square meals a day, so they're doing something about the inmates. It's a good thing, actually, since I think you'll be working for your shelter and for your dinner from now on.” A pat on the lead guard's shoulder causes him to start walking and since I'm connected to him, I'm forced to follow.

I'm led down the hallway passing cell after cell containing inmates who look as if they are being released as well. None of them are violent. In a weird way, I consider them to even be docile, like they are livestock waiting to be wrangled into another pen.

My destination is to the ground floor. The guard lead me to what seems to be the entrance and when the doors open, warm air rushes inside, causing me to squint my eyes. Outside, I see Garcia again, who, without protesting, allows a woman to place a cloak over his head. A van is driven up to where the woman, the guards and the now-blinded Garcia stands. The back doors open and Garcia is led inside.

The guards escorting me lead me to the very same woman. Immediately, she prepares a cloak for my head. Before she can don the cloak over my head, I speak and ask her, “The guard said it's because the government that they're releasing us. That the prison can't afford to house us anymore.”

“It's a new law they passed. The Apathy Clause,” she says and rather happily as well. “You'll be informed more about it later on, but I really do need to put this on your head.” I offer my head by bowing it forward. The velvet fabric stretches to accommodate my hair, but once it's past my ears, it's not as dreadful as I thought it would be. Yes, it blinds me and prevents me from seeing where I'm going, but other than that, it's rather comfortable and doesn't constrict anything. I'm pulled by strong hands and guided into the back of the van, right against another inmate.

“Garcia?” I ask once I'm settled into my seat.

The voice beside me responds, “What is it, puto white boy?”

“Where do you think they're taking us?” I ask him.

“They're not going to kill us since they cannot afford to bury billions of deadbeats. Consider yourself lucky you're in this van, puto,” Garcia says. “Wherever they take us, it'll be better than being six feet under and I can assure you that it'll be better than that cell we shared for the last five years.”

“Last five years?” I ask, but mostly to myself.

“You killed a federal judge, puto. In cold blood, too. You were looking at life. You don't remember this?” Garcia asks after telling me what put me behind bars in the first place. I cannot come up with a reason why or how I would do such a thing. To Garcia's question, I don't answer, which is probably the best right answer I can think of. “Wherever they're taking us, remember you still have your sentence.”

Where is our final destination?
1353333321.title: The Other Side of the Apathy Clause

choices: Take the analogue route
Take the digital route
Refuse to take either route
13533333211.content:
More and more inmates are put into the van until it is filled with bodies, twelve including Garcia and I. The doors close and the engine is turned over. The van is promptly driven down the driveway and judging from the sounds outside and underneath the car, the van is being navigated to the highway. The vehicle picks up speed and maintains it for what seems like hours. Two hours in fact. Being cuffed and hooded like this with eleven other inmates, most of which I probably haven't interacted with, the last thought on my mind would be to fall asleep and lean my head on someone's shoulder. I fight the need to sleep, even though I did wake up from a slumber minutes before being cuffed and escorted to the van.

Before my eyelids close with heaviness, the van abruptly bounces up, which could mean that it might have driven over a pot hole or transferred from the road to a less stable surface. Hearing sounds of rocks hitting undercarriage, I can assume it's the latter. Where would the van be going if it's traveling on gravel roads now.

Soon, the gravel becomes leveled again, but it's not as smooth as the highway, which caused me to almost doze off. The van tilts to its left and then to the right, which I deduce that it's making wide turns. Where could it do that? It certainly couldn't making such a wide turn in a city, so we're probably far from one.

Suddenly the van comes to a stop. I stay quiet and listen closely to any noise outside. A shuffling sound of thin metal can be heard outside and I assume it's a door opening. After the sound stops, the van continues forward until coming to a final stop before it's turned off. The men in the front seats get out and walk over to the back doors, which they open. When the doors are open, warm, humid air enters into the rear cavity. It's a nice breeze that contrasts with the cold interior of the van, but the humidity soon becomes a burden as I deduce where this climate can be located. I would say that driving two hour had taken us away from the major cities to somewhere in the desert. Beyond the sounds of shuffling, as the guards taken each and every inmate out of the vans, I can hear engines. Jet engines to be exact. Are we at an airport? In the desert?

I cannot stay to figure out as I'm pulled out the van with Garcia right behind me. A strong arm grabs mine and pulls me to a spot where I'm pushed onto my knees. An instinct of mine sort of kicks in and it's the action to stay put and not make any sudden moves. The catalyst for this action is the barrel of a gun potentially being aimed at me and my vital organs.

Minutes later, the hood over my head is taken off. I'm finally being given the chance to see my surroundings, but the environment around me does not give me much hope. I find myself in a hanger which is totally devoid of planes. Taking up the space is a bunch of wires interconnected with several computers and unusually, chairs. The chairs themselves spell out execution, but I have a feeling, being released just to be silenced is not what these people are going for. I see the woman I saw before leaving the prison at the front along with other women and of course, two pairs of armed guards. I look behind me and see more armed guard closing the hanger doors.

"Inmates," the older of the women in front addresses the gathering of prisoners. "If you don't know by now, you are all here because of this new law that the government has passed. It's the Apathy Clause. In this law, prisons are being shut down due to the fact that the country of the United States cannot afford to pay for your shelter, your beds, and your three square meals a day. But there is a question that comes up: Where are we going to put you people? As you can see before you, we have set up equipment that will change you. Change you how? We will take your mind and consciousness and store it in a database for six months. In the six months you may think is just one big, yet short dream, but while you dream, we will make new forms for you to inhabit. In these new forms, you will no longer be a prisoner, but be one of many individuals that will help today's society. Well, that's only if you go for this route. There is another route that actually changes your current body."

Another woman, someone younger than the first, steps up and gives us the order of business. "We will go to each of you and ask if you'd like to take the digital route or the analogue route. In either route, we will take off your shackles and proceed to either store your consciousness in the digital route or take you to another facility if taking the analogue route," she explains. Without any delay, the questions begin. I'm in the third row out of eight. Garcia is the on the leftmost side of the group and judging from the first row, it looks like he'll go first when the second row has been catalogued. I still don't know what this Apathy Clause is or what it will do to me. Generally, every inmate seems to knows what will happen to them, except me.

When the people finally get to me, which route should I take?
13533333211.title: Desert Hanger

choices: Annoyed by the fact, it's Garcia and me again
A thin white man with blonde hair
It's Garcia and I on a jet, but not for long
135333332111.content:
When the second row is finished, I observed everyone in each row take the digital route. Each person was taken to a chair and a helmet or headband of sort was placed on their heads. They also were put to sleep with nitrous oxide before anything could happen. From where I was kneeling, nothing really happened. Every inmate in a chair went to sleep and stayed asleep. I wonder if their minds really did transfer to a digital database. They would probably wake up instantly after six months have passed by while those taking the other route would be awake for those six months.

They get to the third row and obviously start with Garcia. I look over and tell them something that I can't quite pick up with my own ears. I wonder if he's taking the digital route. They would lead them towards the back like all the others. On the other hand, I wonder if he'll be the first to take the analogue route, whatever that means. He's probably saying that as a Hispanic man or as a gang member or whatever he is, letting people transfer his soul into a machine is against whatever he believes. He probably also say if he's going to feel anything, he will feel everything they dish out on him. His cuffs are unlocked and the chains leaves his limbs. He's helped up to his feet and rather than take him towards the chairs, he's escorted by a woman and an armed guard to the last row.

I set my eyes straight again after seeing that. Garcia is the first out of the three rows to take the analogue route. I wonder what I should take when they get to me. Should I take the majority vote and pick the digital route, transferring essentially my soul into a hard drive while gods know what they do to my body in the six months it sits without a soul? Or should I take the analogue route, where I believe they will change my body in some way? How they will change it is beyond any guess I can make. Probably they will make me a super soldier to be used in the military. At least that's better than rotting in a concrete cell with a ex-gang member as your bunk mate.

They finally get to me. Even when they ask, "So, Mr. Lopez. What route will you choose?" I look straight on, never looking up to meet the eyes of either the guard who's taking my shackles off or the woman asking the question. I take a deep breath before answering.

"Analogue," I simply say and let the woman do the talking. I picked analogue because I somehow value my body. Even after knowing that I was slapped by my roommate whose intention was to turn me into a woman failed and sent me here, I find that discovering I still have my body is fortunate for me. If I'm to be changed, I want everything to be changed. Everything including mind, body and soul.

The woman takes the liberty to double-check if this is the route that I want to take. "Analogue, huh?" she asks. "Are you sure? Unlike the digital route, this way is more painful, though with time, you can get used to it quicker than the digital route. Are you sure you want to go this way?"

Without delay, like a soldier who has been asked a question by a superior, I state, "I'm sure. I choose analogue."

The woman doesn't question me any more and, sensing she is looking at the guard to her right, I'm brought up to my feet and escorted away from the chair and towards the back. I see Garcia and another man standing near the opening of the hanger. I drop my head, not wanting to look at Garcia, but against my wishes, the guard has me stand next to him.

"Are you following me, puto?" Garcia asks. "You have no score to settle with me, for this I'm sure." He pauses to watch another inmate from the third row select the analogue route and be escorted by an armed guard to our position near the hanger's door. "You think that if he get close to me that I will protect you?"

"No," I say to him.

"I won't, if that's what you're asking. Hope you can do the same," Garcia says and stays quiet after that.

Once all the inmates in the room have chosen, with about ten choosing the analogue route including me and Garcia, the women come over and brief us on our choices. "So, quite a few chose the analogue route. Just to let you gentlemen know, choosing this route gives us the ability to change your bodies directly. It will be painful, since for the first two months you will be constantly under the knife in surgeries or in a chemical tank that will alter your cell at the microscopic level. But it will still be your body. You do not suffer any detachment from your nerves. The finished product will be you, with some changes of course. You will be given two weeks after procedures to recuperate and recover and then the rest of the weeks and months, you will be in training for whatever you'll doing. Just so you know, where you will be after six month will be determined by your efforts. Under the Apathy Clause, where you will serve society is where the government wants you, though we can tip the scales a bit before that."

She doesn't leave time for questions and with a single nod to one guard, the other guards open the hanger and escort each of us outside. Parked outside are private jets and as we disperse, I can tell that two inmates go to each jet.

Which inmate goes with me to our assigned jet?
135333332111.title: Analogue Route

choices: Choose to become his female secretary
Choose the generic fate
1353333321113.content:
Garcia has to be annoyed by now and for the first time, I'm annoyed as well. As much as I want to avoid the Hispanic man with tattoos adorning his upper body, the guards escorting keep rounding us together. We get to a private jet and climb inside. Once we are in the cabin of the plane, there is a beard man, probably in his 50's who pulls out a peculiar gun and without any warning, shoots a silent shot at Garcia. He also lets loose two more for good measure.

Garcia can't do much but take one step before falling back and downward to the floor. Immediately, I put my hands up to prevent the man from shooting me as well. A guard from behind pokes my back with the barrel of his gun, causing me to walk forward. “Don't be alarmed, young man,” the man with the tranquilizer gun reassures me. “Have a seat.”

I walk forward more until I can find a seat that faces toward the tail end of the plane. I find it fortunate I have an instinct to keep any potential danger within my line of sight, as I'm doing now. Once I'm seated, two guards quickly pick up a limp and slumbering Garcia from the floor and sit him down on a seat on the opposite side of the plane.

The bearded man puts his gun away and takes a seat right across from me. He has a face, as if he's observing my face and critiquing it. His squinted eyes and an occasional grin is what I assume to be a favorable opinion of me. After the guards take a seat in the rear most seats, I speak up, “Excuse me, Sir. Can I ask why you shot that man?”

“He didn't have a nice face,” he bluntly says. “You on the other hand have a face that's gentle on the eyes.” I don't have any words or any thoughts that could reply to that remark. Or is it a compliment? “It's a shame you and millions of men have to go through this, but fortunately for you, I'm able to ease it.”

“How so?” I ask. “Will you be pardoning my sentence or at least, shortening it?”

The man burst out in laughter, telling me that the notion of pardoning a man who had killed a judge (but having no recollection of it) or shortening the sentence is so far-fetched, it's hilarious that it was even mention. “You make me laugh, boy,” the man says, but it's the last of his amusement. His face then takes on a serious, straight-to-business expression. “But no, your sentence is not going away, but we can do away with the 'to-life' part. It seems in this society, not even a million dollars can take off a murder charge. But it can sure make a difference.” He pauses, which gives me time to let the word he had said sink in and it also gives me a chance to look this man over. He's old, but not elderly. The wrinkles in his hands and the white in his hair and beard is not signs of age. It's experience. The rings on his hands ties in with it too. With experience, this man has achieved riches. I can sense this man can does whatever hell he want to unleash, if he's the devil. If he's benevolent, who knows what this man can do for someone in my position. “If you are willing, you won't serve a fate that is unexpected. You will live a life that has been set out for you to fulfill with no hidden surprises. Are you familiar with the Apathy Clause?”

“It's why I'm here, right?” I ask in response.

“Correct. Under the Clause, you as a prisoner will be subjected to a changing, a transforming of your physical body. Do you know what specific change that is?” he asks me in return.

I take a guess, “Changing our bodies so that we will be too weak to rebel?”

“You're warm, but not quite there,” the man says, with a bit of amusement in his voice. “Yes, you're bodies will be changed, but your strength level will be different. Do you want to know?”

This question-and-answer part is a game to this man. He's toying with a man half his age. “When you put it that way, I don't think I want to know,” I tell him.

Any sort of enjoyment on his face quickly disappears and goes straight back to a business-only look. He puts his face near mine, but my attention draws to the side and in the shadow of the tail section of the plane. The two guards seated at the back shift and prepare to stand, but it's the man's hand raising that settles them down. “Believe me, if I was in your position, I would want to know everything, no matter how unsettling they may be to my ears,” he says, aloud, but close to a whisper. He suddenly grabs my wrists, which I forget are cuffed. “Your strength will by different, lower than it is now. You won't be able to overpower a man, mainly because you won't be one.” He pauses to let the words sink in. I raise my gaze up from my wrists to his face. “Yes. It will be a surprise for everyone who doesn't become the wiser, but as for you and hopefully Garcia over her, it won't be. And since you've chosen the analogue route and have found yourself on my plane, I will let you know how you will be changed. Do you want to know?”

Knowing there is no other options, I ask, “Do I have a choice?”

The man laughs once more. I understand how this may be funny to him, but I'm not laughing at all. Discovering that they will turn me into a woman is a surprise, but it would be a shocker to be ignorant of the fact and find out once it's all done. “I like your understanding of things, young man,” the man says. “It's good to be prepared, is it not? As for how, the analogue route changes your own personal, physical body. This can be done several ways. For Garcia here, it will be gradual. A couple special injections and a long bath in a chemical tank. For you, you will be subject to a lot more, but it has the benefit of a speedy process and speedy recovery.”

“Is it going to be painful like they say it is?” I ask out of the blue.

The man smiles without laughing for once. “As a matter of fact it is, but consider it this way. Pain is just another way your body tells me you are alive. I believe the more pain you feel, you know how much life is appreciated. Also, pain is your body's way of letting you know that you are healing. Yes, it will be almost unbearable, but I can assure you, you won't have to be bedridden for months as in the case of Garcia.”

“So a woman, huh?” I ask, more like a rhetorical question. The man doesn't add anything and allows me to be pause and gather my thoughts. “What's your part in this?”
